Lots of comments relate to racism, so I think it's worth discussing that a little.

Racism in humans is a very complex phenomenon that can't be simply traced to genes. To be honest, I don't think I really understand racism, but I'm confident saying a full understanding would take inputs from biology, psychology, sociology, and history, perhaps more. But as the video explains, the green beard phenomenon is very brittle and rarely shows up in nature, so it's not an explanation, and certainly not a justification for something as complex as racism.

Thanks for reading, and be kind to each other. :)

“If evolution is about the survival and reproduction of the fittest individuals, then…” stop right there. That is NOT what Darwin meant. “Survival of the fittest,” is not about being the strongest cat or the strongest dog, it is about being the cat that is the best at being a cat and doing cat things. If we are round pegs then the “fittest” will be the peg that fits perfectly through the round hole with the least resistance. It is about filling your biological role in your species’ place in life.

One of the main problems with Green Beard Altruism as it compares to humans is that a human is able to limit its altruism to only the people that it knows for certain are true beards(e.g. its immediate family) as soon as it realises there are a sizable number of imposter and is also able to tell imposters from true beards through many social techniques or simply memory of their past actions, not acting altruistic if it knows the other person to be an imposter.
Thus the imposter/true beard/coward structure is able to find a sort of equilibrium impossible in such a simplified simulation, ultimately forming the basis of our system of limiting the number of imposters and cowards by punishing them with the force of the whole group and serving the true beards better in doing so by limiting the rewards of not being a true beard and making it mathematically unsuitable.

Wait. On the table with 10% death chance, how are there more sacrificed than saved? Are there altruists sacrificing after cowards have escaped? It would be interesting to see the results if there was a random coin flip or something to see if a blob saw the predator. Unless is there?

If not, then the results would definitely favor the cowards, since when one coward is present, one coward always gets away, but when an altruist is there, there's only a 90% chance that they'll get away and a 45% chance for two of them. That makes me think that the cowards might not actually be abandoning each other. I mean, are they definitely leaving a coward behind to die or are they both detecting the predator and running? And what decides who notices a predator and when?

I think it's misguided to even associate complex social behaviors in humans with genetics. One of the unique features of human beings vs most animals is that we have culture and technology. It might seem like our culture is inevitable and immutable because we are surrounded by it, but much of our behavior is learned.

The easiest way to prevent the extinction of this kind of altruism is memory for the individual (throw the other party under the bus if encountering an individual impostor again). This would not stop the extinction of altruism in the model, but it would delay it quite a bit, depending on death rate on altruism. What altruism really needs to survive is communication among blobs, so more or less a basic social system that exposes impostors if the altruist survives and reports. If impostors get exposed, they'll lose all benefits of their role. Under these conditions, I'd imagine suckers>cowards>impostors to be the order of extinction, assuming impostors get no means to defend themselves against being exposed.
Evolution, where every organism gets the Krusty the Klown Seal of Approval, "It's not just Good, It's Good Enough."

Primer: People's actions in real life are complicated and based on more than just genetics, this sim with 2 single function genes will not be able to capture it. In the end it failed but in the next video we'll look at more promising options though.

Without the ability for Greenbeards to detect deceit (could have given perhaps a 50% chance to successfully detect Imposter's deceit), there is a very strong bias against Greenbeards.

Deceit and ability to detect deceit may be seen as analogous of the competition for survival between a prey animal's ability to detect a predator. In this simulation, Primer gave the Greenbeards a large vulnerability in that they would act socially; for the interests of others, without giving Imposters any social accountability. Essentially, the Greenbeards were deprived an essential component of what could make reciprocal altruism successful at a species level.

I would be very interested to see whether Greenbeards would tend to dominate if there were a half-decent probability that Imposters couldn't deceive. In the alternative, there could be a social element to the Greenbeards, whereby each time an Imposter runs away, the Greenbeards have a chance to recognize the Imposter and it's offspring. I strongly suspect that the Imposters would taper off in success after 40 generations or so, with every other species surviving longer: Finally, the Greenbeards would parabolically reach 100% dominance within 200 generations.

One comment about the altruistic / green beard thing is... there IS one way for altruist genes to see other altruist genes (kind of). If they have the gene, they know their offstring probably has it too. Which means they can trigger the altruistic response when one of their offspring (or someone they're related to) is in danger. Granted this isn't exactly how altruism works, but it'd be a perfect example to explain why people are more "altruistic" whithin family groups.

In order for altruism to flourish, it must have 2 things:
The altruism gene must be selfish,
And altruism must have a benefit.

The first and third sets of simulations it died off because it was more beneficial for other blobs than for itself. Thus while it did protect the over all population of the species, the altruistic subset sacrificed itself to benefit someone else without getting as much or more benefit in return.

I suspect that in the real world it works because the population first develops an own-group preference, then develops some form of altruism second, and third is the altruism gene must spread out into the community before being utilized. This allows the altruism gene to benefit itself rather than destroy itself.

I'd rather call "Cowardice" "Self Preservation." If these blobs had brains, they could choose to run away in order to for certain protect themselves - somewhat "selfish" behavior - or they could do it because they're scared - "cowardly" behavior (I'm sure there's many other reasons too). Cowardice isn't a base-level choice to make because it requires a lot of thinking to both be afraid and to not be interested in helping the other person. No matter what, though, running away will always be for the sake of preserving oneself.

For example, imagine if a bear is staring at a stranger nearby you. Clearly, whomever the bear goes after is going to die. In this situation it would make much more sense to run away - you don't know anything about this stranger, but you do know about yourself, and you know that you don't have a death wish. If one of you has to die, you would most likely save yourself. I know that in this case it's a 50-50 that you'll survive, but the point still stands: It's not necessarily cowardice that makes you save yourself. It could just be common sense.

The small flaw of this video is that it doesn't take into account that altruism on a large scale has social rewards, not just individual. This means that people observing altruistic behaviour will feel more inclined to act in an altruistic manner themselves, both in general and specifically with the observed altruistic blob. For the same reason, they will feel inclined to do the opposite for non-altruistic blobs, or even condemn impostors or coward blobs. This means in order to properly reflect the mecanism of altruism in a evolutionary simulation, even if it's just aiming to a simple modle, we need to introduce some ways to detect impostors from true beards with a relative percentage of success.

Two major factors that make "altruism" work in real life but not a simulation this simple:

- In reality, the desire to help others predominantly extends only to those that are close to you, namely family. Given family would share this "helpful" gene, it's closer to the first green beard simulation.
- Not every encounter in real life is a life or death situation. Coupled with the ability to alert others of "traitors", "smart altruism" would overwhelmingly win out over other choices.

And this is just for animals. With humans, their advanced reasoning capability allows them to rationalize the advantages of altruism even if they would not otherwise be disposed to it.

Making my prediction before I continue to the x30 simulation:
Blue will die off in favor of Yellow so long as there is ANY chance that Blue will die, and Yellow will not.
The unrealistic factor here, so far, is the food. Predators eat 1 person who comes to take food, but as long as that predator gets its kill in: the food will always be there for the survivor, aka the coward. In reality; there isn't always enough food to feed everyone, and during trying times Altrustic behavior can increase the survival of the clan, vs selfish behavior leading to wasted food and other resources.
So what we need here is a variable food supple: Each day there could be 100% food, others 90%, 80%, 70%, maybe as low as 50%. This will mean that any time an Altruistic gene gets food on a drought, they will share half of their spoil with someone who didn't get any, while the cowards/selfish genes keep their full spoil, and allow another to starve.
This should, in theory, create a more competitive scenario between them: Will starvation kill off the 'Keepers' before the predators kill off the 'Givers'?

This is the problem that I have with modeling in general. You take something highly complex and try to distill it down to basic components to understand their influence on the systems. However the problem is that most of these systems are indelibly linked and do not exist, or even make sense, on their own without being a part of a deeper system.

To put it another way, eyes don't exist without the ability to move.

Not everything that moves has eyes, but no immovable plant or animal (ie coral) developed eyes. This is because eyes use up a lot of energy, and so they have to improve survivability to be an advantageous modification that persists through generations. A plant that cannot move, but can see a cow approaching it to eat it, gains no such advantage, so it never propagates the trait.

As such, any model that involves trying to see propagation of such a trait in a vacuum is an invalid model. Altruism in a vacuum is one such system.

What I'd be curious about is a person that might get help, who could "pay it forward", so maybe a coward and altruist who meet, where the coward is saved, might have the coward become more altruistic over time

This video is a simple simulation but it fails to account for if the creature is a solo animal or a pack animal. So far it seems to be designed for solo animals with limited socialization. This of course means that altruism is nonbeneficial. As we see in many animals who tend to be loners, they tend to not help their own kind but are actually fiercly territorial (often predators).

Now the simulation has another problem. These blobs seem to be asexual, which completely ruins the genetics race as of course cowards and imposters would thrive, they do not need to watch out for a mate and make sure the mate also survives.

The video recognizes that altruism is an intensely complex circumstance and it would be hard to accurately mimic it in a simulation but simulations have to be aggressively complex for it to be understandable.

For example, creatures in a simulation would need to aspire social circles. Predators would need to be able to threat assess their chances based on strength of social circles. You instantly can see 'cowards' being picked off of the gene pool pretty much instantly if that was added to the simulation. However, imposters... would still benefit from this. Unless there is a situation where an imposter fails to meet their altruistic duty and is outed from the social circle. Thus they'd need to either sneak into a new one, or be left alone and be picked off.

Altruism is most noticed in creatures that have strong family and/or social bonds. Pack animals. You can argue that Altruism is most noticed by many species' parents protecting young. You could say that this isn't altruism but by the definition of putting yourself in harm's way to protect someone else at no benefit to yourself, most animals DO follow this since their offspring often leave their nest/abode, or will turn on their elders when they're older, or even will leave the old and sick to die later. They do not have the understanding or function to care about keeping their species going, but their instincts guide social creatures to put themselves at risk if feasible to protect others for long term survival.

Very interesting video! I'm a bit late to the discussion, but I thought I'd share some thoughts anyways. First of all, I think in creating your "green beard altruism", you've done less to simulate altruism itself, and more to simulate in-group mentality. From your simulations, it'd clear why in-group mentality is so powerful and pervasive in human psychology and behaviour, which is so cool! However, in-group mentality and altruism are fundamentally different. Secondly, I think one of the main reasons why your Pure Altruism (ie suckers) genes were culled so quickly comes down to your operationalization of altruism. in your simulation of Altruism, you failed to account for the basic fact that being nice to people makes them like you, thus increasing your reproductive chances. Higher reproductive chance would offset the cost of saving cowards and increase the beneficial aspect of saving other altruists. I'd be interested in seeing a similar simulation as this same simulation if you played around more with the reproductive chance between altruists and cowards. Alternatively, you could go the slightly more in-depth route of making it so blobs could only reproduce if there were two blobs in the house, so there would be an active benefit to more blobs getting home alive.

Actually I think the cowardice vs altruism kind of says something about society but not in a hopeless way and more in a warning sense. Cowardice wins out but it’s based solely on individuals in the environment and whether they live or die, in this sense cowardice makes sense because if it’s just you then you’re definitely going to try and survive and put yourself first.
However Altruism is beneficial in that it would allow a community to survive for longer. Altruism would more likely lead to the blobs defending each other and maybe even causing the predators to avoid them. Which means more potential mates and young would end up surviving.
E.g. When chimps band together to attack an incoming threat. Some may die, but the group, including its costly young would survive. If every chimp ran away then the slow and the young would probably all get destroyed and the chimps would have to exude a lot of effort to make more young and have a next generation.
So even though cowardice wins in a selfish emotionless environment, it wouldn’t be practical in the long run. So a purely social darwinistic society where every individual only acts in their sole self interest would probably not survive in the long term, or atleast not with a large sustainable population.
Maybe that could have been demonstrated if cowardice had a lower chance of reproducing than the altruism (less mates) or perhaps an energy penalty (since each individual would have to gather for themselves instead of sharing food)
(Not a criticism of the program, just adding my opinion)

Joshua Risko's comment about 'converting' to altruism touches upon the basic flaw of the model. Behaviours don't spread within the generations, that is, there is only natural selection and not social selection. In real life, in-group selection is fluid and associative rather than determinate. Saving someone creates a bond that makes those someones more likely to reciprocate in the future. In-groups form naturally through similarity and proximity, sure, but they also build through social mechanisms.

My problem with this, is that there is no objective benefit to altruism here. Pretty much any example in nature gets something out of helping, whether it be protection, to exclusion (not being on a predators list), or something else. A more accurate depiction would be to have reasonable blobs (sacrifice food to the predator for the sake of survival) and reasonable predators (which accept such offerings), reasonless blobs (which would rather fight and die for their food) and reasonless predators (which take offerings and the blob), give them random altruism/cowardice/other personality, food sources that require more than one individual to obtain (but doesn't necessarily feed them all) which can cause groups to form that forces predators to group up (whether with other predators or blobs) to take down them down, etc.

Basically, the "added complexity" is more breadth then depth. More mechanics, but no way for those mechanics to interact. Shallow, in other words.

Your examples are flawed...
The reason altruism works in humans (and other species) is because of the benefits of being in a social group as opposed to having to fend for yourself...

Altruism on its own has no value to survival... what it does instead is strengthen the social bonds between you and the people around you making it more likely that you can trust the people around you to help you when you are in need... if they can trust you to help them when they are in need... which in turn makes it more likely that both you and your group will survive...

And there is still a surviving rate if you have to fend for yourself (just not as high as if you have help... but it is not 0% like in your examples)...

And lastly... there is no 'green beard' in real life... there's is nothing outwardly physical for you to identify whether a person is altruistic or not...

The way people determine altruism in real life is by actions...
If somebody has helped you the last 5 times you needed it... it's a pretty good bet that they are altruistic (at least towards you)... so you are therefor more likely to help them this time where they need help to insure that they will keep helping you in the future.. i.e. making you altruistic towards them...
Whereas if they didn't help you the last 5 times you needed help... you are less likely to help them because they are probably not going to help you in the future anyway... so why risk it...
And if most people help you when you need it... you will be more likely to help a stranger you know nothing about too... because chances are higher that the stranger too is also altruistic and by not helping them you would lower the chance that they will keep being altruistic towards you in the future...
And if most people don't help you when you need it... you will be less likely to help a stranger you know nothing about too... because they too are probably not going to help in the future anyway... so why risk it...

So if you really wanted to test if altruism would work in real life... here's how it should be done to get accurate results...
Everybody starts out with a statistical chance (maybe 50%) of being altruistic in the moment towards the other blob or not...

And that is split into 2 values: (at the beginning both the same... i.e. both 50%)
1. towards that specific blob
2. in general towards other blobs

And those 2 values change over time up and down depending on how often the blob itself has been saved by another...i.e. the blobs learn from their experiences with the other blobs (the more it has been helped the more likely it is to help another blob in the future and vice versa)...

Ex: (feel free to change the values of the example to see what the results would be)
First you set the survival rate if you are or are not warned... let's here say 90% if you are warned and 10% if you are not warned (i.e. you had to fend for yourself)...

So let's say they all start with a 50% chance that they will be altruistic...

And then if they are saved by another blob:
The chance to be altruistic towards the one specific blob that saved it goes up 3% (to 53%)...
And the chance of being altruistic towards all other blobs goes up 1% (to 51%)...
Because it was saved with the help of another blob... it have learned to trust other blobs more and the blob that saved it specifically a lot more...

And if they are not saved by another blob (but survives by fending for themselves):
The chance to be altruistic towards the one specific blob that didn't save it goes down 3% (to 47%)...
And the chance of being altruistic towards all other blobs goes down 1% (to 49%)...
Because it had to fend for itself... the blob have learned to trust other blobs less and the blob that didn't save it specifically a lot less...

That way... the more the blob helps others the more they are likely to help it in return and the more likely it is to survive in the future... because over time to more help it will get from others... you risk more now to help others so you risk less overall (both for yourself but especially for the group as a whole) when they help you in the future...

Now run simulations with different surviving values, starting values and learning values and see the results... and you will have a WAY more accurate simulation on altruisms impact on survival in real life...

Racism is rather complex but it is probably mostly psychological and sociological but it does have a solid basis in biology. It occurs and reoccurs as part of a us vs them strategy of behavior and that makes racism closer to group selection or aggression towards your competitor. For humans there are 2 obvious reasons for that. One if the opponent is given more chances of success then they may outcompete and destroy your group or lead to less chances of you and your relatives from passing on traits. The second reason we are more complex with the ability to create and obtain culture. Culture acts as a second form of inheritance for both the group and individual in question. So this may have it's early beginnings in smaller groups competing with other groups that had different sets of learned behavior "culture" than you

Altruism in asexual reproductive cycle with no parental requirements wont place value in this trait.  The moment 2 genders are involved, ie male and female, the altruism gene retains value as a altruism expression implies a reproductive advantage and synergy value proportional to the altruism in propagating those genes, in contrast to a disadvantaged reproduction from a purely selfish relationship.

Wish I'd found this video sooner because I was discussing with another ethically minded friend and (I love love love you content, don't get me wrong,) but I think we skipped some steps on this one. The real flaw in the system, whether the altruism be 50% or 10% chance of survival, was that cowardice had a 100% survival rate, 0% environmental threat. They always had the choice to run away and no chance of being caught during flight anyway. This would cause their gene pool to sky rocket in any case. Then altruism gets redefined as... well... not altruism. Rather it becomes, as some other commenters have indicated, a type of racial exclusivity, a selection process that in and of itself differentiated non-green beards as "other" and in a way, "sub-human." This defeats the beliefs that altruism propagates. Just thought it could be interesting to revisit this sim and even the playing field a little. I feel that acknowledging the flaw in the system could have been as simple as adding a third sim that acknowledged a flight risk to cowards, not allowing cowardice to always win out in the end  but have its own environmental cautions. Perhaps fleeing blobs would have to escape from every neighboring monster and given that they encountered too many, they would perish anyway. I'm rambling at this point, but I hope I made it clear enough what I meant.

I was thinking that in real life, certain types of altruism is rewarded isn't it? We often see articles of "heroes" and "this person saved my life" or "helped stray dogs" or whatever, or the hero of a village might be rewarded with gifts from their rescued friends. Of course, we don't reward EVERY act of altruism we see, but the rewards that we do see seem pretty impressive ("Wow, they got famous!/They got a cash reward!/Their family thanked them and is willing to help back, etc.") Maybe some people, after seeing how the altruistic are rewarded, might start thinking (even if just for selfish reasons) "Hey I want that! I'll act heroic and maybe I'll get rewarded too!" even if the chance of actually being rewarded is really slim. Some blobs might start pretending to be altruistic, and maybe the true altruism gene still does end up dying, but because other blobs have started to copy the behavior in hopes of being rewarded, maybe we're left with a pseudo or learned altruism; something they weren't born with, but was taught by watching. In a sense, that way Altruism is maintained, if not genetically, behaviorally.

But it could work the other way too. Maybe blobs nearby sense when an altruistic behavior ended in failure. That stuff publicised is publicized a lot in today's world too. Maybe some altruistic people start suppressing their altruism in fear of death, though I guess that wouldn't make them truly altruistic.

Maybe we need an inbetween population. The greenbeard blobs who are dead set on staying altruistic, the yellowbellied cowards who are dead set on running, and maybe a percentage of undecided flip flop blobs who shift opinions based on what they see. Who knows. Maybe true altruism dies but lives on in the learned behaviour of adaptable blobs, maybe cowardice dies out instead, or both, and all we're left with is adapting blobs with fake/learned altruism or learned cowardice. Who knows.

While simplistic, this perfectly visualizes the concept of the "Dog Eat Dog" world we live in, where we don't mind helping others, but we will ALWAYS help ourselves.

Essentially, if we are capable of assisting others to survive while we also survive, it becomes beneficial for us to work together. But if our own personal aid toward others is met with too much of our own personal sacrifice, we either seek to take advantage in other ways, or give up entirely.

In short, those who genuinely need the most help while offering the least in return are doomed to failure, while those who offer the least help while taking the most for themselves are destined for success.

My summary:
if evolution is about the survival of the fittest, why are creatures sometimes nice to each other?

the basic simulation rules
there are blobs, trees, fruits, predators
every day the blobs go out to the forest to eat some fruit
each tree has enough fruit for 2 blobs
some trees have predators. if the blobs visit a tree with a predator in it, the blobs get eaten
the blobs that are not eaten, reproduce and create 1 or 2 new blobs
this cycle repeats

sim 1 (basic simulation):
no altruism, no cowardice
1 run
-this system is mostly stable

now the altruism is introduced
if the blobs go to a tree with a predator in it, one of the blobs will notice it. it can then do one of 2 things:
cowardly behaviour: it will run away and the other blob will die
altruistic behaviour: it will warn the other blob (the other blob runs and lives), but itself will have a chance of getting eaten
the cowardly or altruistic behaviour will depend on the blobs gene
in reality, behaviour is complex and dependent on a lot of factors and their environment over time

sim 2:
altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
50% chance of death on altruism
1 run
-the altruism allele goes extinct

sim 3:
altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
10% chance of death on altruism
1 run
-altruism allele goes extinct

sim 4:
altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
10% chance of death on altruism
30 runs
-altruism goes extinct in all except 1 run (close to extinction tho)

why did this version of altruism fail?
sim 4 data:

saved sacrificed net gain
all 225817 24151 201666
altruists 85781 24151 61630
cowards 140036 0 140036

number of blobs saved doesn't matter, by itself.
blobs saved now just means more blobs to be eaten later
what matters more is the competition between alleles
a successful allele needs to be able to help itself more than it's competitor

how can this be done?
one way is to let the altruism alleles see each other so they know who to help
there needs to be a detectable feature to go with the altruism.
a classic example is a green beard

if the blob with a green beard notices a predator, it will warn the other blob if they have a green beard


sim 5:
green beard altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
50% death chance on altruism
1 run
-cowardice allele goes extinct

sim 6:
green beard altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
50% death chance on altruism
30 runs
-cowardice allele goes extinct

sim 7:
green beard altruism and cowardice
50% of both blobs
90% death chance on altruism
30 runs
-there are a lot of fluctuations
-there is an average upward trend

sim 8:
green beard altruism and cowardice
10% of green beard allele
50% death chance on altruism
30 runs
-there is a rise on average
-in 11 runs, the cowardice allele goes extinct
-in 19 runs, the green beard allele goes extinct

sim 9:
green beard altruism and cowardice
10% of green beard allele
90% death chance on altruism
30 runs
-there is an upward trend

it seems like the advantage of having a green beard increases as there are more green beards

to make the model more realistic, now the gene controlling green beard altruism and a green beard will be different

so now there are 4 blobs
GB altruism no altruism

no beard suckers cowards

green beard true beards imposters

sim 10:
suckers, cowards, true beards, and imposters
25% of each blob
50% chance of death on altruism
30 runs
-the altruism allele always goes extinct
-the suckers go extinct first
-the true beards go extinct second
-then the number of the remaining 2 groups, the imposters and the cowards, bounce around randomly

there are a few examples of this found in nature (the papers of these studies are in the description of the video)

in short:
1) altruism with no strategy altruism goes extinct
2) green beard, single gene altruism survives
3) green beard, 2 genes altruism goes extinct

I think the problem here is you are treating altruism as risking the blob’s life for another unrelated blob: it would never be evolutionarily viable to risk your own life for unknown blobs, that simply doesn’t make sense evolutionarily as it minimises the chances of your genes being passed on and maximises that of your “competitors”.

As you say, humans are generally fairly altruistic, but very few humans would risk their life for a stranger. Altruism then is other things, particularly sharing resources. Hence, this could be simulated much better by giving each blob a chance of getting fruit, e.g 30%, to simulate “foraging”. It must get >1 piece of fruit each time. Then, impose the restriction that if a blob goes 3 days without fruit it dies. From there, code two behaviours: altruism and gratitude. Altruistic blobs would give one of their fruits to others who lack fruit, grateful blobs will not give food to just anyone who is short, but will “repay their debt” if their altruistic friend is short. You’d quickly see that altruism greatly aids the groups chances as a whole of survival as well as the chances of survival of each altruistic blob - provided there’s enough food, if the food is so lacking then the altruistic one will just aid its own demise

This theory actually dates back a long time, I’d guess Kropotkin (anarcho-communist writer) was the first to point this out in “Mutual Aid: A Factor Of Evolution”

The reason you see altruism disappear so fast is because altruism carries no immediate benefit to the individual, which isn't necessarily the case. Saving someone's life would naturally form a bond with the individual you saved. That's obviously horribly complicated to show in such a simple simulation, so the closest you can get is to increase the number of offspring or the chance of producing offspring on a day where an altruist survives; to sort of simulate that whoever they saved decided to shack up with them. Say, flat chance of 50% to produce 1 offspring and 25% to produce two, but if a blob saves someone and survives it becomes 100% to produce 1 and 50% to produce two.
This isn't quite accurate to real life, as it treats interpersonal relationships as a bit too transactional, but it gives a better idea of why altruism may have a better chance of surviving than selfishness. Self-centred creatures tend to be alone, much like spiders.

I think altruism exists because people are a lot more complex and full of different emotions. And the carrots on a stick for being altruistic are a lot deeper than just the concept of you either live or die. The carrot on the stick for altruism in reality often has to do with improving one's environment. By being altruistic they directly affect their surroundings in a beneficial way. Giving a sense of better living conditions which reinforces our own joy knowing that by making someone else better we also reap some reward from it. The idea of there being an incentive of dying vs not dying just does not represent well enough the vast amount of complexities that go into the decision in nature for altruism. I am interested in seeing this same simulation but with a small variation:
1) Altruistic always helps
2) Coward always runs away
3) If 2 altruistic meet, chances of survival increase for both (because both will be distracting, dividing the attention of the predator)
4) If 2 altruistic meet and survive, there would also have a chance of bonding (forming a team, a comunity or so on) which would make them actually go searching for food together (aka increasing that pair chance of survival in subsequent runs, but not their descendents)

Basically, giving altruistic 2 reasonable buffs. This could be interesting also if done removing conditions 1 and 2 and having trying them with the altruistic only helping beards, but giving the "suckers" a chance by having them have a 50% chance of "helping first" and then getting help in return

I think this are reasonable conditions that could make for interesting simulations. You could further complicate it by having it so that if a pair meets with a third blob or another pair at the tree, there could be detriments, just to keep the population under control.

I think altruism actually is seen more, in the more dominant and developed species on earth. You certainly see it less in bugs, a greater amount in things like elephants and apes, and much more so in highly intelligent, planet spanning, attempting-to-bounce-to-different-world-ing beings. The reason of course is that once we can communicate our needs to one another, we can co-operate in highly specialized ways. The more of us there are to co-operate, the more of us there are to do things like break through confinements and barriers with sudden moments of eureka, and so forth.

So we all take care of each other because each one of us is an increase in the odds that we’ll live longer, more enjoyable lives. Love and enjoyment are huge factors. I mean, we are, after all, creating simulations within our world purely for enjoyment, we’re creating VR that has nearly zero real-world differences on our survival odds.

We have to be ultra careful for impostors though, because a small percentage of the population is psychopathic and sociopathic, and they are absolutely drawn to positions of power. This is why we need to construct systems that decentralize power as much as possible, if we are to survive as a species. This is likely also why, a system of altruism like the checks and balances of the constitution of American leadership made way for some of the fastest advancements of mankind we have ever seen on Earth.

Now imagine just how amazing we’d be if we took what it was that made the original set up so decentralized, and pushed it further yet, in that decentralization direction. Away from systems like communism, and away from authoritarianism, through unelect financial gigantism.

The problem with this experiment is that in social animals the benefits of altruism is group survival. If a group cooperate and show some degree of altruism behaviour between members of the group they will improve the survival of the group. Group with very little cooperation will have more chances to disappear or been destroyed by more cooperative groups. Specially if group fight for limits resources. This explain herd behaviour. Individuals in cooperative group has more chance of survival than individual in very selfish groups. There's a balance between inward pressure for selfishness and external for cooperative behaviour.

It is important to point out that white supramacy should never be confounded with altruism - because it is not. Violence is not altruistic. The communities that actually practiced altruism are Black, Indigenous, POC - racialised and other marginalised communities, that is - with our long history of mutual aid. Racism is systemic and institutional - racist policies in law and financial and power establishments, and the corresponding racist discourses in media and education institutions. Acts of altruism are, however, separate and individual - even when it's following a universal rule as in green beard altruism, the acts upon which altruism is granted is still dependent on isolated interactions, which is again why each run has a different result regardless of having a general trend or the lack thereof, because it is driven by independent interactions that are happening by pure chance. Racism does not happen by chance, and racism is systemic. Racism operates on the scopes of politics, economy, education, psychology, medicine, beauty, technology, etc, every area of life, but it is not created by a combination of factors within them. Racism is created by hundreds of years of racist policies, practices and discourse that effortlessly propogates and reproduces itself except on the rare occasions when people had modest success interrupting the cycle just momentarily. I know the channel creator is white and is therefore not expected to know a whole lot about racism let alone anti-racism. But it is an important moment where we hold ourselves accountable and start to learn about race and anti-racism, and have meaningful conversations and take meaningful actions.

I think the problem is that altruism works best in a group. The key differences are that the bigger the group, the safer you are (so being selfish and letting the members of your group die will in turn make your life harder), and that an individual that acts selfishly can be expelled from the group, which makes their life a lot harder.

In other words, i think altruism is much more effective in groups than in individuals only meeting occasionally, which would explain why it didn't perform well in your simulations.

Models two (cowardly vs altruistic blobs, 50% chance of death if altruism triggers) and three (cowardly vs altruistic blobs, 10% chance of death if altruism triggers) appear to have the results they have due to a MAJOR procedural flaw: no mention is made of whether cowardly blobs can fail to escape predators. The observer can only assume that cowardly blobs will always escape predation, making their survival inevitable.

That concern aside, I personally suspect that the simplistic coward/altruist model could have been more successful in an environment with a higher proportion of hazardous trees to safe trees. My reasoning is that the effectiveness of a warning call increases the more blobs are warned off by it. There is still the risk that the cycle will just repeat until the altruists have yelled themselves to death until there's not enough altruists visiting the same tree to benefit from this effect, and the additional risk that a high enough predator population might decimate all of the blobs outright, but it is feasible that the simplified model might achieve equilibrium under some circumstances.

Though in practice, even if cowardly blobs can fail to run away, there's also the flaw that there's no elaboration concerning how effective warning calls are relative to cowardly behavior. Can the warning call fail to alert blobs? Will the chance of a cowardly blob attempting to flee be affected by the presence of a warning call, and if so by how much?

EDIT: The green beard sim has the same flaws, and relies on the assumption that the cowardly blobs will completely ignore warning calls, so I'm just straight calling bullshit on the utility of this simulation.

During the first runs, you should have given the warned blob a chance of survival rather than a get-out-of-jail card. Otherwise, the altruist blob takes on all the risk and none of the rewards. This would also take into account the predators behaviour and the possibility that the warning call was not effective, as it sometimes happens in nature. I would argue that the first runs are flawed because they failed to take into account some basic game theory (from a simulation perspective) and animal behaviour. It gives the "cowardice" blob an overwhelming advantage and, at the same time, it negates the positive effect of a warning, i.e that the predator's chances of a successful catch are diminished since both possibles pray are now alerted.
A better altruism vs spite simulation would be to pit familiar groups against each other, where individuals could discriminate between relatives and non-relatives and help or hinder accordingly (like competing ant colonies for instance). @primer

You could have programmed the simulation to factor in whether the altruistic blobs witnessed an act of cowardice from a cowardly blob within a certain proximity of their tree. This blob would be, in a sense, "marked" by that altruistic blob, and word would be communicated to other altruistic blobs not to rescue that blob because that blob would not rescue them. It's an ethical approach if one uses the golden rule as a guiding principle.

By stripping the blobs of awareness and decision-making, you remove a key driving force behind natural selection, particularly in social groups. I'd be curious to see what happens when you make the adjustment I've mentioned, and then include a diverse set of variable genes that determine the decision making process.

For example, you could add a gene that determined whether or not the altruistic blob would ever mark a cowardly blob. Or whether or not they would communicate it with the rest of the "tribe".

So this video basically sums up what I've come to realize in life:

We all play a game. As with every game, there are rules to it. And everything works flawlessly, as long as no one breaks those rules.

Though... Whenever someone does break the rules, only those who broke them actually benefit from it. Everyone else who keeps playing by the rules loses.

In this video's case, the "imposter" blobs aren't playing by the rules. They pretend to be part of the green beards, but don't act like green beards. Which means they benefit from other green beards who play the game by the rules, while completely leaving them at their mercy by not returning the favour.

Honestly, everytime I realize this, I kind of loose faith in humanity and get a little sad. I hope that in the end, players who follow the rules come out on top and players who break the rules get punished accordingly. Though my experiences in life tell me this is not and will never be the case.

It seems fairly easy to explain in layman's terms:
Humans have a natural disposition towards wanting to protect whichever "group" they belong to, however they choose to identify said group. It may be national, political or even based on shared hobbies, just to name some examples.
That means there is a natural "us" and that everyone else is "them", until proven otherwise. In order to protect the group from "them", you instinctively learn to identify what makes "them" different from "us". Racism is simply a label that is applied when the identified reason registers to "them" as something that has to do with ethnicity.

Every culture on earth displays this, as do the vast majority of people, even those vehemently opposed to racism, sexism and various other "-ism's". They simply protect their group from "them" by focusing on other differences, for example to keep opposing political views or troubling opinions out of their groups.

i think the issue with this simulation, and why you didn't come up with an explanation for altruism persevering, is made clear in the swap between tracking total population in your very first simulation to tracking proportion of traits within the population in all your following simulations. i would guess quite confidently that a species as a whole does better when it contains altruistic members, and from that would go on to (less confidently) predict that once the altruistic trait is bred out of the species, the species itself would die out as a result. i was really surprised and a bit confused when you stopped tracking population following the first simulation, so i'm surprised you didn't present this idea yourself (not trying to be rude by this though, it's still a great video).

tldr; i'd guess species where altruism isn't present are less successful than species who possess altruism, meaning even if altruistic species are rarer, they're far less likely to die out (you can track population along with proportion of traits within it next time to test this)

Cowards shouldn't have had a 100% chance to live, in real life fleeing from a bad situation doesn't automatically guarantee you will successful escape the situations effect. (ex running from a bear or wild mountain lion would likely increase your chance of death)

B. Each of the 4 groups could have a chance to "freeze up" or hesitate and get killed instead of rolling the dice with their natures. (cowards, altruist, fakers, followers)

Here is how I would do it

****Start Of My Preferred Simulation****

I think in the end the only way to gauge this in these tests is to have altruism like this. One species is fully selfish and cowardly, the other is altruistic. I also think you need far less tress, so there is more competion. Each individual creature can only live 4-5 cycles at most, and no longer. Every creature needs 1 food to live but be hungry, 1 food to live and be full, and 1 additional food to procreate the cycle after. Only getting 1 food at the end of the day will result in 1 day off your cycle max, and 0 with instant death. Every tree has 12 food on it, and some have predators. When going to get food, if 2 or more creatures go to the same tree, whoever got there first gets a choice. If they are altruistic they will divide the food equally, regardless if the creature they are sharing with are altruistic or not. They will not dive lower than 2 each, so anyone who doesn't get anything will die. If a selfish person gets there first, they take 10 food and leave the 2 for the next person to grab it. They will take it without a choice. Getting 10 food in a day will result in a 10% speed boost for the next cycle only. For tress with predators, Selfish and cowardly creatures will take 1 food and have a 80% chance of fleeing safely. Altruistic creatures will do the same, and both will remember that tree being dangerous. If 2 or more creatures go to the same tree with a predator in it this is what happens. If 1 only creature is altruistic, it will risk it's life to save the others, so it will have a 50% chance of survival and should it survive it will get 1 food, while all selfish creatures have a 100% chance to get away with 1 food, however, there is a 15-25% chance they will become altruistic themselves for the rest of their life. If 2 or more creatures are altruistic, altruistic creatures get away with 2 food each, and each have a 75% chance at getting away unharmed, the selfish ones get away with 3 food each, and a 30% chance of themself as well as their future children to turn altruistic. All creatures will once again remember which trees they encountered, though memory only lasts 1 cycle. At the end of the day altruistic creatures will tell their adjacent neighbors which tree was dangerous, so they can avoid that 1 tree the next day. If that neighbor was selfish and didn't know about that tree already, then they have a 15-25% chance of becoming altruistic. Selfish people will still avoid that 1 tree in the next cycle, however, they will not inform their neighbors.

****End Of My Preferred Simulation****

****My Reasoning****
Altruism shouldn't only go to altruistic people or you miss the point. I believe altruism is inherently a beneficial thing for one's own survivability, so to me all altruism, is selfish alruism whether you intended for it to be or not. Altruism helps with 2 things. One is one's own mental health and happiness. People more willing to be truly altruistic are reported to be vastly happier than people who are either not altruistic or are selfish. Human beings are also naturally sociable, even introverts, since time alone without any communication to any living being, human or otherwise, can leave us feeling depressed, and can actually cause us to lose some of our sanity. The second point is on the same terms of sociability, but this involves trust-building. Altruism breeds altruism whether we intend to or not, whether that's toward other humans or animals, building trust has many personal benefits toward one's own survivability. Whether that be directly for survive or simple to support us mentally. Animals even do this too. Certain mammals take in and care for other animals and birds, instead of eating them. Whether this has happened in their pack before or not, many animals still show tendencies to do this. Intended or not, many of those helped animals actually help with overall group survival chance. For example, birds can alert mammals that sneaky predators are nearby, while smaller mammals help gather grubs from harder-to-reach locations. Group actions make food hunting less of a daily risk and vastly more stable. Ants have been shown to save or sacrifice their own lives to protect others, regardless of species, though it is often strategic. For example a specific breed of fire ant that is capable of taking down certain larger animals when in high numbers, doesn't do so even though it would make them safer, instead they often feed, take care of and take the food intended for the predator, nearby an enemy ant hill. The predator kills the enemy ants, while choosing not to kill the ants that helped it. Doing so results in stable food and safety for all parties. True altruism will always be a little subjective, since true altruism will always help us in return, either as an individual or as a species. More people who survive and are happy and healthy leads to more minds boosting the economy and or making strides in science and medicine, making life even better, and that's true whether or not we consciously thought of that while helping. Selfishness is a pretty straightforward and static way of operating. It's ol reliable. But altruistic behaviors, although potentially taxing, have a strength in numbers effect that helps altruistic people as well as selfish people

All this really does is providing a very basic model for the fundamentals of selfishness and altruism, both being words fabricated to give context to something very complex that can't be quantified in a simple video with a simple simulation and that time and again defies expectations, both for better and worse. Some are simply disposed towards helping others, even at risk to themselves.
Life experience will tell you however that in order for selflessness to survive, effort, intelligence, and nuanced understanding are needed. Neither of these things are being displayed here.
For instance, logically those blobs should have ran away while yelling, that would have eliminated the risk to them entirerly. Also this simulation runs without any modifiers during its course.
In a similar real scenario, people would come together to find a solution to the problem with simply exterminating these predators being the resulting main goal. That's what humanity have done already, the cities we live in proves that. Finally, since these blobs are just simulations, they are incapable of reflecting on their actions, have an empathic response, or be driven by the flock instinct we humans share. They literally just see an existing condition and follow orders, no questions asked.
The sad thing is that there are some people who don't think deeply about the human condition and just takes basic simuations as gospel. For instance, why are there comments about racism?
Racism is to judge based on appearance and origin, what is being displayed here is an us and them mentality with care only being given to kin. There are so many factors to create sides - shared history, family, mutual interests, matching idealologies. Racism is the last thing you should assume. Goes to show what the world is like today I guess.

So anyways, while this video doesn't prove anything, or explain anything beyond basic concepts, it does provide a lot of avenues for critical thinking on the human condition, by presenting concepts that invites to said thinking. I think we, as a species, need to capitalize on such opportunities and keep our communications open and the debate flowing. That's how we rise above being mere animals.
And mere animals will kill you for being different. Did you know white ravens are not actually uncommon? But their mothers usually kill them in the nest for being white. And those that survive are doomed to live as loners, shunned by other birds for their unnatural color. Let that sink in for a moment. Maybe the racism comments weren't completely out of place on second thought.
But bottomline, communication, or rather nuanced such, is not presented here and that is what differentiates us from animals. We are watching a simulation of animals. And we are never further from it than our best efforts.
Have a peaceful day, planet earth.

This simulation is such that "imposters" have a 100% success rate to fool "true beards."
The next logical step is to vary that parameter. Presumably, there are opposing forces between the inherent benefit that "true beards" get as a group, and the inherent cost of helping "imposters" who never reciprocate. If imposters are sufficiently UNsuccessful, then they may not incur enough of a cost to drive true beards to extinction. Surely there's a "sweet spot" where the two forces balance out.

Of course, imposters are incentivized to push their success rate to maximum. But true beards are incentivized to detect imposters. Thus begets a co-evolutionary "arms-race." Such gets increasingly interesting (and I think stable) if true beards evolve a "retribution" behavior. Currently, imposters receive no downside to taking advantage of true beards, even when they fail to convince in the above modified case. Being subject to a cost-benefit scenario (rather than pure benefit) seems like the mathematical basis for stable, complex systems of traits, as opposed to "run-away" traits taking over.

It's not really a good simulation because there is no consequence for saving the other blob. The AI doesn't have feelings/fear, so if it sees 2 options, A and B, and both have 100% of 1 blob surviving, but the other has even the slightest (10% in this case) chance of 2 blobs surviving, then it will always choose the save option. There is no selfishness programmed here.
It's also interesting to see the development of only altruistic blobs or only coward blobs and see how the difference in numbers over time changes because of their personality.

The issue with this is that it's only measuring competition between different alleles within a species rather than competition among species, meaning it doesn't show how the dominant allele impacts the survivability of the species. An imposter allele will win against the others in its own species, but it won't benifit the species against the predators like the green beard allele would. There's been a lot of simulations done like this that show that the green beard allows a species to gain an overall benifit for itself against other species, while a trait such as the imposter allele allows the imposter to exploit within its own population, but ultimately caused the species as a whole to fail. The entire thing fits quite well to the model of humans, just imagine how less you're willing to help someone that's exploited you, while you and your friends both gain extra chances of success from each other's support. I don't have any links on hand, but this area has been a hot topic for as long as people have been thinking so there's plenty of studies and thought experiments out there for people who are interested that show just how absurdly powerful an altruistic species is, a famous one is the altruism prisoner experiment I definitely recommend checking it out.

So... you misunderstood the phrase "survival of the fittest" at a basic level in the introductory premise. I've not watched past that yet, so I'm unsure if that was intentionally done to draw in audiences and nod to the fact that the majority of people make that error in relation to the phrase. But, I'll point it out anyway... "survival of the fittest" refers to those who fit best. Not the fitness of the individual, but the ability to fit the role they play in their environment. Case and point, the extinction of the dinosaurs, who were generally both physically and mentally superior to just about anything else on the planet, including those who survived long after the dinosaurs were gone. The environment changed, and they were no longer fit to survive it, plain and simple.

This alone answers the question of altruism without the need for further explanation. After finishing the video, I noticed that the simulations also have some pretty glaring flaws... the "coward" behavior guarantees a surviving coward and a death. In addition, reproduction utilizing only a single individual renders the population total pointless, as well as prevents the mixing of genes, thus nullifying the benefit of altruism altogether. An increasing trend of cowardice is literally guaranteed given enough time, with the rules set in place. Further, the variation in population total in general was pretty high, as shown by the control group, whose population dropped down to half in a relatively short period of time, then recovered.

I assume that at some point, you will be doing a video on reciprocal altruism, which would require coding for blob recognition and memory. You may also want to simulate collective reward/punishment vs individualistic reward/punishment.
Under collective punishment, each blob observes the behavior of every other blob and any time a blob witnesses another blob acting cowardly toward any other blob, they remember that individual cowardly blob and deny them altruism the next time that individual is encountered. Under individualistic punishment, blobs ignore how blobs treat other blobs/blob families and only remember how particular blobs treated them (or their direct ancestors) in past interactions. Of course, you would need to model a non-zero chance of survival upon visiting a predator tree and not being warned in order for individualistic punishment to have any potential value.

A protocol to simulate learning can be based on the prisoner's dilemma repeated several times (between 5 and 10) per generation for each blobs every Xyears. 2 selfish blobs don't cooperate they have 5 years malus (-50% for the next reproduction). 2 cooperatives blobs have 6 month malus (-5% chance for next reproduction). 1 selfish against 1 cooperative, the selfish have 0 malus and the cooperatives one 10years (-100% for next reproduction).
But those who don't cooperate have have a risk of retaliation (x% of malus next reproduction. For example if they come across Y cooperative blobs how have been betrayed) out side of the dilemma from those how have cooperate and have been betrayed. That could simulate a reputation. And a risk of retaliation during next dilemmas if they are against a cooperative blob who has already been betrayed by a non-cooperative blob (5 years each => -50% next reproduction).

As you pointed out in the beginning of the video, the environment, personal preferences and other factors also play a very important role.

And although this altruistic feature can't be seen directly in real life, I think there are 2 important phenomena here:

1) TRUST: We tend to protect others who we know and that we believe that would help us out when needed. We probably also have a tendency of helping people with familiar features, but that's just me guessing.
A more general approach to that could be that, for every time a blob is helped, there's a chance that it will become altruistic.
Blobs perceiving that they've been deceived (or even someone near) could also help trustwise.

2) COMMUNITY: Although there are no definitive visible features that can tell one's behavior, being part of a community (family, tribe, profession, tattoos) can play a big role on the visuals and body language, which in turn contribute to perceived trust.

I think one of the most important aspects of altruism isn't the relative frequency of genes within the population, but rather the population size itself. Altruism works because it gives the group a survival advantage so there is massive selection pressures for the group to generate and cultivate traits that help one another.

Yes it still has to compete with the other genes in the population so that part can't be ignored, but altruism wouldn't be nearly as prevalent if it didn't affect group vs group competition so much.

A stronger altruistic test would be the family/tribe model. A single green beard goes out and gets food for a group, returns and shares it to the group, they then reproduce based on the energy they acquire. Loved this video! It basically explains why the Green Beard effect isn't seen that often in nature - basically there are two parts to being a "true" Green Beard 1) having a green beard 2) helping out other green beards. But the first part gets you all of the benefit, and the second part gives you all of the costs. So if these parts are coded for by different genes which are inherited seperately, the gene for having a green beard will do well, but the altruistic gene will go extinct. And it's very unlikely a single gene can code for both parts.

The reason it works in fire ants is pretty cool! What's acctually happened is that a huge section of fire ant DNA has become locked together, so all of the genes in that section are always inherited together. From an evolutionary point of view they act like a single giant "supergene", which can code for loads of different things at the same time, including both parts of the Green Beard effect. Supergenes are fascinating and can do so many other interesting things, including things which sometimes seem to defy the basic principles of evolution!

From what I understand, altruism in humans is mostly tied to our ability to feel empathy. If I remember correctly, altruism in nature is related to the number of creatures saved, meaning it's more likely for a creature to sacrifice itself to save a whole pack or herd than it is for it to sacrifice itself for one creature. Altruism is also likely if it reduces the chance of losing anyone at all, such as a herd intervening to save an individual from a predator. One of the intervening creatures could be lost in that attempt, but the chances are much lower. Don't quote me on this, though.

It made sense that the self sacrificing gene would go extinct every time, because a blob with that gene simply has a greater chance of dying with no benefit to more offspring. It can die by getting eaten the same way as a coward blob, and it can also die by warning other blobs. Any arbitrarily low chance of death by warning will always result in that gene dying out, unless it also gain a benefit to more offspring somehow (which wouldn't make it altruistic)

Maybe the model was too harsh - altruism resulting in immediate death.
There are a few others that can be suggested:
1. An altruist who nearly avoided being eaten may get some "scar" that increases its chances of being saved next times.
2. In the model, propagation is done by simple "cell division" while we rarely observe this in life - two partners are involved (except the most primitive forms of life). The "scar" from above may be an "attractive sign" for partners.
3. In the model, all gene holders were randomly mixed at each step. Perhaps, forming small subpopulations where one gene predominates, and competition between these subpopulations for territory will increase the altruistic gene survival, as they may promote the growth of its own subpopulation more than others.

From my limited understanding, in natures, creatures that display altruism, like bees are usually the individuals of the species unable to actually procreate, after all, the drones will sacrifice themselves for the hive and the queen, but if the queen would die, the whole hive would. None of the drones can reproduce. So altruism in nature is just a way of getting more use out of automatons that will be obsolete with time anyway. Since not many species operate on this behaviour, actual altruism is scarce.

green beards aren't rare in humanity at all. the blobs here had to use beards because they can't otherwise communicate. humans have much more complex ways to identify who is worthy of your altruism, and to what degree. it's not based on appearance, but reputation. you're willing to put yourself at some risk for someone with whom you have a good rapport or who has a good reputation. in modern society, we pretty much assume almost everyone else is also somewhat altruistic to at least a minimal degree. for example, you see someone drowning, you'll try to help. you assume they would most likely do the same for you. if you knew that the other person is a jerk, sociopath, murderer, or whatever, then you'll be less willing to do anything for them depending on the severity of their reputation and the situation at hand.

I think altruism is better tested in a system simulating a creature with 5-10 days to live and a pair living situation. Reproduces every 5 days. All blobs start out with a white mark. When an altruistic blob sees a blob not helping, the coward gets their mark turned black, and the altruistic blob will turn green marked and go home at the end of the day and tell it's partner and neighbour about the coward. An altruistic partner and the altruistic neighbours will then turn green too, and avoid helping black marked cowards, but keep helping those without black marks. Every 5 days, the altruistic blobs produce a little blob that's either white marked or green marked (and therefore knows from day 1 that black marks are bad) and that a mixed parent altruistic/coward offspring (red mark) have a 50/50 chance of being coward or altruistic, and thus red marks have a 50% chance of being helped by an altruistic green marked blob and 100% helped by a white marked. If a red mark is witnessed being altruistic, the red mark turns white, but if it is shown as a coward, the mark turns black.

I think the biggest flaw here is the mixing of the different traits.
Animals that have social structures (like wolves) will interact mostly with animals that have the same/similar genetics to itself as they stay with their pack which is mainly composed of direct relatives to one another. Most days they won't encounter other packs with different traits. Because of this I think that it would be more accurate to do different independent simulations of an entire population with the same trait (altruistic or not) and to monitor the populations size.
Basically I don't think it is very likely that an altruistic creature would save a non-altruistic creature as it is unlikely that the two would meet as such creatures are also likely to be pack animals with territory that stay in their packs which are made up of mainly family members (who would also share the same traits).

This strengthens my faith in Christianity. When I argue in the uniqueness of human altruism and morality, the usual response is to point out anecdotal evidence for altruism outside of the human species. This just goes to show that, given evolution, we should expect to see the occasional altruistic behavior in animal species, but that it would likely never become prevalent. Human beings, who remain altruism despite the evolutionary disadvantages and despite the presence of "imposters" still largely remain altruistic, if not perfect in their moral behavior. This is some extreme fine-tuning, and lends credence that the moral law is "written upon [our] hearts."

Fortunately, altruism doesn't follow a binary "dead/not dead" outcome in real life. Genetics only cares if you successfully reproduce enough times to carry on your genes before you die; anything else is a bonus. This is why bad genes and aging persist. As long as you lived long enough to reproduce, it doesn't matter to the continuation of your genome in the long run. In the modern world, there are plenty of opportunities to be altruistic which have no significant impact on one's chances of reproduction or survival; our present attitudes are simply evolutionary holdovers from when they were actually necessary for daily life.

I think the logic behind these simulations are flawed. I think the main benefit behind altruism isn't purely based on saving another, but in reciprocity. Each of us have a complex set of traits that make us good at a certain selection of tasks, and bad at another. If I am good at something and bad at another, it benefits me to help out my counterpart, someone who is bad at the things I am good at, and good at the things I am bad at, as long as they reciprocate the generosity.

Good clean system. I'm not sure what hamilton's rule is but I think the way to account for real life altruism is to make a percent chance to reproduce. Altruistic mates have a higher chance of creating offspring as it is seen as a beneficial trait by their mate and that offspring is more likely to live on to create more offspring.
Altruistic blobs have an 75% chance to reproduce each cycle while coward blobs only have a 50%.

This reflects what we often see in nature where animals without altruism or a social mentality will often mass reproduce (like fish spawning) to offset the loss of their future offspring to predators. All the whole social altruistic animals will have small numbers of offspring per reproduction but their offspring are more likely to survive to reproduce.

I think altruism was mainly produced by the fact that some genes may not be immediately favorable but also not deadly, and so in a relatively small tribe the genes leading to altruism may be present in more than one instance as certain mutant traits get passed down even if they're not necessarily the reason for being passed down as long as the individual manages to reproduce, and then because altruism is advantageous to the tribe, the tribe itself has a better change among other isolated tribes, upon various events which would otherwise bring the tribe to extinction.
In the end the tribes which had some altruistic individuals have a higher genepool presence than the tribes which have been more likely to go extinct. Then there's social factors, if you have a 50% chance of survival after being altruistic, it may lead to altruistic extinction but if that raises your chances of reproduction to say 90% to 100% as well as giving you more option for reproduction, which means the chances of a fit and successful baby are higher by the fact that you get to choose the fittest partner to reproduce with, then the social advantages may lead to more food being given to your family, furthering the offspring's chances of survival, as well as social inheritance passing down privileges through the generations much as it happens with tribe chiefs or kings in medieval times.
Compared to a biological early life fear of dark, I think altruism is still quite uncommon as a trait, although present in the majority to some extent, it's definitely not universal by the standards of other native instincts.

The pinned comment tries to downplay this result's relation to racism, but I think the point is being missed. It's not racism, in particular, that this is a model for, it's TRIBALISM. That's literally what the green beards are doing: Only warning those of their own tribe, and ignoring those of the other tribe. And as shown in this model, that behavior works evolutionarily, for the simple reason that it increases survival rates of the tribe to prioritize those within the tribe over those outside the tribe. Racism is, broadly speaking, an outbranch of tribalism; humans have been programmed by this "benefit the tribe" bias to prioritize, in general, people with similarities to themselves, because that correlates to being part of the same tribe. Skin color is easy to notice, and so the "benefit the tribe" function in our brains laches onto it. Whether this ultimately benefits any group is beside the point, and trying to sort that out complicates matters unnecessarily.
