I mean, since the blobs are just 1’s and 0’s and they don’t have a conscience, I’d assume they would very quickly learn that yelling to warn the other blob is the statistically best scenario for the longevity of its species. They run away, there’s a 100% chance of a blob dying. If they yell, there’s only a 50% chance, pretty straightforward. Now of course this is hard to replicate if the goal of the blob is to achieve the best “life score” and stay alive and repopulate, because then it won’t care about the other blob, it’s not going to risk a 50% chance of dying and having a worse life score, it’s gonna take the 100% chance of living and just run away. Good way to combat this to actually give the blob a choice to make, is to make it so that say each day a blob survives they earn 10 life score. By reproducing they earn an extra 5. Say by eating the food they only have a 75% chance of reproducing to make it so they may have to go out and try again and risk death. Now, if the blob goes to a tree and is the one chosen to notice the predators, If they do nothing, let’s say they get their +10 life score for surviving that day, but they don’t get any food that day, so no chance of reproduction, and the next day if they do get food, their chance of reproduction is only 25%. So it’s a bit of a penalty to have some consequence for saving themselves. Now if they notice the predator and warn the other blob, if they do get eaten, their life score is still increased by say 5, so they sacrificed themselves for a higher life score, and the next day the blob they saved now has a 95% chance of reproduction. Now if they yell and survive, their life score is increased by say 15, and the next day both them and the blob they saved chances of reproduction are both 95%. This means for the blob that notices the predators, they have a choice to make, either guarantee their survival and get their 10 guaranteed life points, and still have a chance of reproducing the next day even if it’s a smaller chance, or risk themselves with a 50% chance of dying, to guarantee 5 life points and the blob they save having a higher chance of reproducing the next day, or a 50% chance of living, getting more life points for being brave and risking their life, and both them and the other blob both having higher chances of reproducing the next day. Also in this scenario the blobs goal should be a hive goal. The simulation should be run for say 100 “years” and the goal of all the blobs is to have the highest average life points. However obviously a certain percentage should be put in who’s only goal is their own personal life points. And each time a new blob is born they have a certain percentage chance of being either for the species, or for themselves. I don’t know what the right percentage should be for that but let’s say it’s a 20% chance. Might be a bit high but would be cool to see the balancing point for all of these factors.

This would make it so that some blobs make their decisions based on what they want to risk or think is best for the species to get the highest amount of life points, and some make their decision based solely on their own goal of achieving the highest amount of life points. This is unique because the blobs only caring about their own life points may still yell and warn the other blob for the chance of surviving and bagging more life points than if they didn’t, snd then having a higher chance of reproducing which would also get them more life points. While some trying to look out for the entire species may not warn the other blob....oh wait no they would warn them 100% of the time because if they didn’t there’s only a guaranteed 10 life points and then a lower chance of reproducing the next day, vs if they did there’s 100% chance of a guaranteed 15 life points for the species with an even higher chance of one reproducing, with then a 50% chance of if both of them having a higher chance of reproducing. So maybe you don’t make it a guaranteed death if the blob doesn’t warn the other, maybe that blob still has just a 50% chance of surviving and also have a lower % chance of reproduction the next day. So then the blob looking out for the species may not warn the other blob as it would still guarantee 10 life points, and still have a 50% chance of that blob surviving. Oh but then it still won’t do that because by warning them it’s a guaranteed 15 points with better reproduction chance vs a guaranteed 10 with lower reproduction chance, and still with a 50% chance of the other one surviving with a lower reproduction chance as well. So maybe instead, by not warning the other person, the blob gets guaranteed to live that day, and also earns 1 food but with a lower chance of reproduction that day, say 25%, and so then had to go out the next day with a chance of dying and getting no more life points. So the blob can either warn the other blob, guarantee 15 life points and the other blob having no chance of reproduction that day, but having a higher chance the next day, and then having a 50% chance of surviving and also having a higher chance of reproducing the next day, or not warning the other blob, guaranteeing only 10 life points, but also getting food that day giving them a chance of reproducing that day but at a lower % chance and also a lower chance the following day, with a 50% chance the other blob will survive and earn another 10 life points and have a chance to reproduce the next day as well.

One key component that does emerge from human complexities is a measure of accountability we know as reputation.
People's natural inclinations manifest reputation as an important aspect of how we relate to each other.
Degrees of altruism vary greatly according to the level of trust between individuals.
Reputation is human natural social currency used to trade in trust with one another which modulate altruistic behavior.
Outsiders disconnected from our social awareness are thus often treated with an attitude opposite of altruism.

It’s worth noting, and perhaps encouraging to hear, that while a single gene very rarely codes for a “green beard” and for altruism, it is common to see linked genes. Linked genes are essentially different sections of the same long strand of dna (or rna, depending on the organism). What this effectively does is create a correlation in the alleles. In our little blobs, that would be represented by having very few imposters or suckers.
Of course this is an oversimplification, and doesn’t account for mutations, increased complexity with multiple genes coding for one trait, or any number of other factors. However, it’s encouraging to see, and poses a possibly hopeful future for more complex versions of green beard altruism.

greenbeards only work if the trait they look at actually indicates altruism. The single gene system shows this, but you missed an important in-between for that and the 2 gene system.

If the allele distribution is uneven, with truebeards and cowards far outnumbering impostors and suckers, then truebeards will come out on top on average as long as the initial distribution of truebeards to impostors makes it so that a truebeard sacrificing themselves to help an impostor is less likely than a truebeard helping another truebeard and surviving.

Or alternatively, impostor and sucker individuals tend to reproduce back into truebeards and cowards if there is sexual reproduction due to their genes being non dominant
Now replace "green beard" for "white skin" and you've got yourself a pretty good model of the world.

I think this would probably change a bit if you took into account inherited genetic traits. I bet altruism will make sense if you gave priority on who to save based on how close it was genetically. They'd save family but ignore those that are not family, direct descendant you'd save for sure, distant uncle, not so much. They could also do a risk evaluation, where they'd definitely sacrifice themselves for a direct descendant, but would not take a high risk for an older family member or far removed family. Only when the risk decreases does it make sense to expand altruism to include blobs outside the family. People work like this, when they can take good care of themselves they can expend more energy on immediate family, once they can take good care of family they can start expending energy on the community they belong to, once that is sorted they can expend energy on the country as a whole, then the world, then animals, then all life, then rocks and light and what have you. It seems to be going on a scale from most like me to least like me. Hence we tend to care about apes and cats before we care about squid, and squid before we care about grass, and grass before rocks and so on. Also why we care about our children more than our neighbor. If not for society/tribes being able to keep direct family relatively safe we wouldn't care about the society/tribe. Altruism, or compassion, isn't as built into humans as many of us would like to think, it just seems natural to us because many of us are borne into a society where we and our family is in no direct danger, but if we and our family was starving having compassion for that neighbor with lots of food would go out the window pretty quick. So I think altruism comes from the same basic drive to want to live that all life has, and since we can't live forever the next best thing is to make sure our genes survive, then that our community/way of life survives, then that our species survives, then that our habitat survives, and so on. It all seems pretty logical to me and I think your simulation failed because you treated altruism as trait instead of a hierarchical mechanism.

it might be tempting to draw conclusions from this. but don't forget: real altruism is tons more complex than this. you have to factor in relationships over time (game theory works totally differently when the interaction is repeated), smaller sacrifices (altruism doesn't always have to end in death, for example giving a poor person a few dollars doesn't mean you starve), and the human tendency to be superstitious. there may be truths that can be gained by exploring this model, but don't forget that human social structures are far more complex than this.

@Primer I think the kin selection would really be the big thing here.. If you had two genders, the one that selects and one that tries to impress (in this case with altruism). Lets call them Selector and Impressor. So for example if a Selector has the altruism trait it will only select an Impressor with the altruism trait, where there would be a certain view radius. So if a Selector sees an altruistic minion in its radius (Sucker or True Beard), it will follow it home, whereas if it doesn't see anybody altruistic in its radius it will go home with someone it thinks has the altruistic trait (True Beard or Imposter). And the Selector without the Altruistic Trait will go home with anybody.

I have some clarifying questions:
(a) How effective a survival strategy is running? It can’t be 100%, or else the altruism is meaningless, but it can’t be 50% or less, or else an altruist incurs no extra risk by helping the other blob.
(b) What impact does an altruist’s warning have on the other blob’s survival chances? Is the other blob certain to survive if given warning, or does it just have a better chance? If it is certain to survive with warning, an average of 75% of blobs in coward-altruist encounters survive, so the chances of a coward surviving without warning must be less than 75% for the altruism to beneficial to the overall population.
(c) How do survival chances change when two altruists encounter a predator? Is one chosen at random to receive the benefit of the other’s altruism, or are both blobs more likely to survive? They can’t both have only a 50% chance of survival, or else the green-beard altruists would be less likely to survive encounters with each other than with cowards, and so wouldn’t have taken over the population.
I’d be interested in how tweaking all those numbers influence the overall trends, but more importantly, I think knowing the odds of survival for any given pair of blobs encountering a predator would help me understand the results better.

I’m also curious what the overall population sizes are for all these scenarios. I wonder whether the trend that appears in your hawks-and-doves video, where hawks become dominant even though more doves means a higher total population, would translate to a scenario where selfishness is a lower-risk scenario instead of a high-risk, high-reward one, and altruism risks the altruist’s life instead of just lowering its reproductive chances, but maybe I’m getting ahead of myself there. @Primer
I think this simulation is a little too individualistic and I have some suggestions as to how to simulate the more complex behaviors in a general manner using 6 alleles, but divided into 2 groups of 3.

So here's my proposal: add groups to the mix, call them "packs". You need to be a part of a pack to reproduce. The chance of an individual reproducing is proportional to the number of individuals left in the pack at the end of the day.

There are 2 groups of genes, each with 3 genes, each pack has just 1 from each group. We'll call them the Altruism Alleles, and the War Alleles.

Altruism Alleles (only 1 of these 3 alleles per pack):
1: Cowardice
2: Altruism toward everyone
3: Altruism toward pack only

War Alleles (only 1 of these 3 alleles per pack):
A: Throw non pack members to the predator to get away.
B: Throw pack and non pack members to the predator to get away.
C: Total pacifist, does not try to throw anyone to the predator.

If two come together that try to throw each other to the predator, only one survives and it's a 50/50 chance as to which one.

To give cowards more of a chance, due to their paranoid nature, if someone tries to throw them to a predator, give them a 50% chance of avoiding being thrown to the predator, and the one trying to throw them to the predator also a 50% chance of being eaten instead. Meaning there's a 25% chance they both get away, and a 50% chance of one being eaten.

Also, if two that come together show altruism toward each other, it should reduce the chances of either being eaten, because they're actively helping each other.

Caveats, some combinations are incompatible as they would produce contradicting behavior. So I propose two versions.

In version 1, which contradictory behavior is performed should be chosen by a 50% random chance. For example 2B (Altruism toward everyone, and Try to throw everyone to the predator), 50% of the time they would choose to throw the blobs they meet to the predator, and the other 50% of the time would warn them..

In version 2, the contradictory behavior allele pairs like 2A, 2B, and 3B are excluded from the simulation, bringing the simulated groups from 9 down to just 6.

I predict that group 3A will have the greatest chance of dominating the simulation, though I wouldn't be surprised if 2C and 1A are also top contenders. The other combinations I haven't the foggiest idea of how they will fare, but I do expect 1C to not fare well at all as any time they run across an A or a B at a predator they'll die, and the smaller a pack becomes, the harder survival will be.

These modifications to the simulation are simple but should simulate many more complex and emergent things we observe in the real world. For example, the sexual reproduction of the more complex creatures that are needed to even have altruism in the first place. It'll also better simulate the fact that small populations are more vulnerable to extinction. It'll also simulate tribalism, and it allows altruists to identify other altruists without the need of colored beards. Well, sort of, it should be assumed that pack members can identify each other and thus choose to help each other. It's not a perfect "only help altruists" but it does allow for simulating multiple behaviors that are chosen based on in-group, out-group distinctions.

This should produce fascinating results.

One element of altruism which should be remembered is that it never really exists in a vacuum, we only really see it in animals who have a major social structure. Like Meerkats, where the colony by and large depends on each member being altruistic (which they do by being a lookout for predictors). This altruism directly corresponding to the health of the colony, and without a strong colony the risk of death increases for ALL Meerkats, including the ones who would be 'selfish'.
I say this because in the simulation you don't have communities where the altruism gene would cultivated in the real world, you have a collection of individuals who don't really have much in the way of a social dynamic (which you more or less state when you mention the weaknesses of the experiment).

I'd like to suggest a next step for your simulation:

Implement a notion of collective consciousness and meta-awareness towards each blob's own group. For example, when blobs are in the garden, they are capable of witnessing the actions of other blobs. If a (true) green beard saves a blob, then news spreads and the collective consciousness holds that green beards are now a bit more likely to save than not. And vice versa, if a green beard (imposter) does not save a blob, then news spreads and the collective consciousness holds that green beards are now a bit less likely than before to save. The effect of this is that "belief updating" can take place via probabilistic updates from the record of events. The necessary followup feature to this is that each group must also be self-aware concerning the community's beliefs towards them.

If it's within the communal beliefs that green beards are no longer as likely to save other blobs, then the true green beards will be cognizant of this and will adjust their likelihood of saving others. This is a much more complex mechanism, of course, but one I'd argue is much more realistic.

If true green beards realize that green beards are perceived as less altruistic, then should they increase their likelihood to save others? Would it save their group identity in the collective consciousness, but risk higher rates of death? Or should they decrease their likelihood to save others out of preservation of self?

Oh so many interesting questions could be asked and answered (potentially) if this were implemented. Please do consider!

Would have been good to see the total populations for the other sims as well:
A gene may not be competitive with other genes, but populations (of many different genes) may all benefit from that genes presence, such that other genes evolve to help the altruism gene. This would be the evolution of a population rather than the evolution of a particular gene.

I would expect the stable population of sims containing greenbeards to be higher than those that do not contain greenbeards. And these smaller populations are more likely to go extinct. So the evolution of greenbeards may be encouraged in this way.

For example, I bet the pure greenbeards or even just sims containing stable populations of greenbeards rose to a higher population than those where the greenbeards went extinct.

And I think that would answer this running question of where altruism comes from despite its poor competitiveness. The scope of evolution may just be larger than you are thinking of it in.

I would say this is too simple to really test the point of altruism & evolution. Especially in the first test the altruistic blobs aren't lacking a way to survive, that's looking at the problem all wrong. You have designed the simulation so that in more possible cases the coward blob survives, so of course the crowd blobs come to outnumber the altruistic blobs. This doesn't reflect nature. The altruistic blob is taking a risk, it's taking a chance that it might die. The coward is taking no extra risk. But this coward sort of behavior also comes with a risk that your simulation does not account for. A simple way to control for that would be to give the crowd a chance that he never leaves his house and starves. When more of the possible out comes result in the death of one blob type, and you assume random chance makes all out comes likely, then of course that type of blob will die more.

Altruism isn't always purely selfless, at least not for group animals. Me doing something good for a member of my group would actually benefit me too since they're in my group. Like I share food with my brother, then later on he saves me from an animal. But each one of these blobs is entirely alone, and never has to face a different sort of threat that another blob (that they have helped in the past and therefore earned good will with) is better suited to face.

Plus no blobs can ever change in this model. The blobs that receive help have no way to then help the altruistic ones later on down the line. Behavior of basically all (learning) animals can change during the course of that animal's life based on past experiences. For example, if a blob could change from one group to the other, or know if the blob in question has saved their life before (or if their ancestor did, since each day is a generation?). Generally, a human that has multiples other humans help them over the course of their life, but refuses to give any assistance or kindness to anyone else (even family) is consider to be mental ill (narcissistic/ASPD/sociopathic/etc.).

I don't get how the cowardice behaviour prospers when it 100% of the time gets a blob eaten - while the altruistic behaviour only has a 50%/10% chance of getting a blob killed?? One ALWAYS loses a blob, the other does it 50% of the time?

I think the main problem with the simulation is that there's no learning or post-escape benefit associated with the altruistic action.
Humans learn to avoid predator plants, they learn to adopt survival strategies or not. Altruism in the real world doesn't predicate on an absolute chance of death or some other grave negative outcome, though in a grossly extreme scenario that might be the case. The fact that society and civilization have made human communities so safe allows for docility and kindness as a part of participating in the social group to be a viable strategy.

Once enough people accept altruism as an overall beneficial strategy, more people learn to be altruistic, and once it becomes a socially acceptable (or rather, socially expected) action, then the situation flips and it becomes a disadvantage NOT to be kind, as you risk being ostracized by the group.

The requisites for altruistic behavior would seem to be:
1) Recognition: A means by which organisms can identify "trustworthy" peers.
2) Aid: Selective altruism towards "trustworthy" peers.
3) Removal: Discouragement of "imposters" sufficient to separate them from the gene pool.
4) Reward: Encouragement of altruists with increased mating opportunities.

1,2,3 OR 1,2,4 OR 1,2,3,4 are sufficient.

My guess is that "altruism" likely has deep roots in tribalism and probably a very violent past. In order to meet the third condition, one must rely on subjecting "imposters" to imprisonment, exile, mutilation, or murder. Really interesting how this kind of tribalism would get its start. Clearly recognition of ingroup / outgroup was the first to evolve but I wonder what order 2,3, and 4 may have evolved in.

What about group selection? If there are two hives, all else being equal, the group with the more honest foragers will win. "Honesty" in this case is a function of how accurately a forager's dance (sacrifice of precious calories) reflects her true assessment of a flower patch's quality. The bigger her lie (disparity between sacrifice and assessment), the greater the misallocation of foragers. Let's say that her true assessment of a flower patch is 100 calories, but she only spends 5 calories dancing, then she personally saved lots of precious calories, but way too few other foragers will visit the valuable patch, to the detriment of the hive.

But what if there was another youtube, all else being equal, where the "thumbs up" button was replaced with donation buttons. I could click a quarter button on your video. My sacrifice would still be less than my true benefit, but it would be greater than simply clicking the "thumbs up" button. These videos follow the format of..
1) simulating social behaviour (with the optimistic starting assumption that altruism will arise naturally and inevitably),
2) the simulation doesn't give an answer you are comfortable accepting, so you keep changing the experiment parameters to try and force it to prove humans are altruistic. Even the cheating fails.
In science we can have expectations, but we also need to accept when the results repeatedly don't agree with our deeply cherished ideas of what is true.
We dearly want to believe that humans are mostly altruistic (against all available evidence), but in general it just isn't true.
This is why society has laws, to curb people's (evolved) selfish behaviour.

Why didn't altruism do well in the simulations?
1. In real life, you have a bigger chance of helping someone that is genetically related to you than a random person (helping staying the similar genes alive)

3. the simulations only simulated individual vs individual but many animals, including humans, live in groups and it also matters how does a group do compared to other groups

One issue I can think of is the lack of communication and memory. In the 2 gene simulation, the impostors are able to become dominant because they can get away with their behavior as the truebeards don't remember who's a truebeard and who's an impostor, nor are they able to warn other truebeards. Similarly, the suckers have no chance because no one ever remembers their sacrifice. So, here's how I suggest we modify the experiment:
1. As usual, you have suckers, cowards, truebeards and impostors.
2. If, at a tree with a predator, a truebeard encounters an impostor, it remembers that specific individual is an impostor.
3. If, at a tree with a predator, a truebeard encounters a sucker and survives, it remembers that specific individual is altruistic.
4. If a truebeard encounters another truebeard and both survive, they exchange their information.
5. If, at a tree with a predator, a truebeard encounters anyone they remember is an impostor (either from a previous encounter or an information exchange), they will instead act cowardly.
6. If, at a tree with a predator, a truebeard encounters anyone they remember as altruistic, they will act altruistic whether the other individual has a beard or not.

The points you make are valid, but the simulation is too simplistic to accurately represent altruism in humans. The main missing factor is the fact that humans are social, and in our evolutionary past, we existed almost exclusively in tribal groups. The main reason this matters is that tribal groups enable reputation. Their population is small enough that each person can memorize & maintain a reputation for every other member of the tribe; And, the population is small enough that you are forced into repeated encounters with the same people (in other words, your past reputation actually effects future interactions). Reputation alone is insufficient; for example, even if every person in New York City had the biological capacity to remember a reputation for all 8 million people, there are so many people that you could be a jerk to everyone you meet and never encounter them again; as long as you moved around enough. Tribal groups solve this by limiting the number of people you can interact with, such that your reputation actually affects you in the future. This is further magnified by trusted relationships between tribal members, such that reputation propagates faster & further. In other words, if you exploit my friend, your reputation with me changes just as if you had done so to me. This internal system is protected by making a behavior distinction between those inside the tribe, and those outside it. While kin selection is beneficial for the bootstrapping of such a gene-behavior, once the gene is established, direct kinship is no longer necessary. All that is necessary is stable membership to a semi-small group. This system will protect against imposters, and pressure them towards extinction. An impostor exploitation strategy will not work more than a few times, within a tribal group; and you cannot jump around between tribal groups to leverage this "first-time" exploitation opportunity, because people outside the tribe start with a negative or neutral reputation, and in-group preference only applies once an individual has attained a positive reputation; tribal members are born with a moderate positive reputation (i.e. kin-selection); strangers must earn it. And the degree to which in-group preference is applied to you, is proportional to the amount of good reputation that you have. So, while a stranger may have earned enough good reputation to engage in trade with the tribal members, or exchange information, they may not have enough good reputation for the tribe to risk their lives for them, or let them intermarry with them, or even to allow them to sleep overnight in the tribal encampment, etc.

I think that one aspect that would factor in is some level of discrimination. People observe a small set of traits and behaviors and will make a generalization about the person - after all, humans love to subconsciously or consciously read into patterns. Your last example had green beards having no relation to altruism whatsoever, which is similarly reasonable to all beings with some particular trait definitely being altruistic... that is to say, not reasonable. The answer is somewhere in the middle: We might be wrong, and save someone not altruistic, but our subconscious is good at spotting and reacting to patterns, so a non-insignificant amount of the time we will be right. Whatever this success-at-spotting-altruism (or broadly, success at spotting worthwhile/good individual) rate is, is the key that needs to be integrated. Both the guaranteed spotting altruism and the impossibility of spotting altruism don't account for this flawed but often convenient tool of pattern discrimination we have built into us. Work on a non-zero (but not guaranteed) failure rate and see what comes of it!

Also, of course it's worth noting something other comments brought up: You can earn trust. Past experiences will factor into your "credit" as an individual, so to speak. The rate at which other individuals with flawed "good person detectors" will dismiss you over earned distrust, even if you otherwise sit in their pattern of high likeliness for "goodness", matters just as much as the rate of detector failure the judging individual has.

The problem is that even if altruism is better globally, being a coward or an impostor is better locally. When everyone is altruistic, it's the best possible option for the population, but then it is better to be the one who gets all the help and doesn't sacrifice himself. It's a classic prisoner's dilemma.

Awesome vid, though I found the direction you took this was to be somewhat unexpected. It may be better framed through negative and positive outcomes associated with behaviors. For example, if people observe you being a coward, they are less likely to accept you in society such that your post-survival mating potential is reduced. If people observe your altruism, they are more likely to accept you into society such that you're post-survival mating potential is increased..

So the genetic equilibrium is where the "net cost" of cowardice is equal to the "net cost" of altruism. In each case, the net cost is the conditional probability of passing on genes as a function of (first) P of survival, (second) P of attracting a mate if survival.

Encoding altruism into genes is also problematic. In reality altruism is a learned behavior, which opens the door to all sorts of game theory complexity.

You made an obvious mistake at the end. There is no correlation between the two genes, so of course it's going to be a bad strategy to self-sacrifice for an uncorrelated gene. The "green beard" and "altruism" genes need to be strongly correlated for it to be sensible to work, otherwise the strategy is obviously nonsense. The right way of doing this last step is to make green beards have a much higher probability of having altruistic behavior (this is realistic in nature because some genes are physically close to each other and have a higher likelihood of being carried over.) I think a more interesting model would be to not consider altruism or cowardness, but an actual spectre of self interest. At the end of the day both altruism and cowardness are symptoms of the same thing. Everyone wants to do the best for themselves, and the best for themselves can either be self preservation or saving someone else if that someone else is a very big influence for them.

As such, you could do it like this:

1- Everyone has a factor (0 to 1) that determines how much they value someone else (lets call it A for altruism)
2- For each pair of blobs (Blob x and blob y) you have two 0 to 1 factors that determine how important each one is towards the other (X->Y determines how important X is for Y, and and vice versa).
3- Then, when a blob X is trying to decide wether to save blob Y, you can do A * Y->X, and set a threshold above which X decides to save Y. This way the model takes into account both how altruistic X is, based on how important blob Y is for X, while giving him the option of saving himself if Y is a total stranger.

Then you'd need to find ways of changing the X->Y values. To do so, i'd do it in a couple different ways:

1- Whenever X saves Y, X->Y increases, because X is grateful towards Y
2- For every day that two blobs survive, while living in the same household, increase both X->Y and Y->X (If you want to study something like family bonds)
3- If X does not save Y, give Y a chance of survival, and if Y survives, reduce X->Y, so Y is less inclined to save X if he has been abandoned before.

With this kind of base model there are a lot of different ways of exploring interpersonal bonds and can be complexified as much as you want.

Isn't passing on altruism more based on who survives, as well as the success of the population surviving overall.

Example: Blobs only go out to hunt AFTER they've had a child. The number of hunters to return determines the number of children to survive (at random). There is a stable population before the altruism gene is added. When added, a blob with the altruism gene will risk its own life if on average that will result in more hunters returning. A blob population grows while it maintains the altruism gene, and on a macro scale the standard break-even populations are quickly miniscule by comparison.

In other words, it's not about whether altruism is good for the individual, it's about whether it's good for the population. The problem works backwards from the way you're looking at it, where the population that finds a way to propagate altruism is the one that will inevitably become dominant by numbers.

This does paint a pessimistic picture for altruism, but I think it's incomplete and here's why:

I think we use social pressure and social rewards to increase the altruism of those around us so that we can benefit from their altruism. We venerate and enthusiastically interact with altruistic individuals which makes their reproductive prospects more successful.

In response, natural selection has found some benefit in altruism because others reward it so much socially.

Being an imposter is a strong strategy, but once the individual is exposed as such, they stop getting the social benefits that come with altruism.

I think it's interesting how, despite the simplification of "green beard altruism" from an evolutionary perspective, it still bears a lot of similarities with the real world. Human behaviour isn't so simple that an individual is either altruistic or selfish. Each of us is a mixture of both and both genetics and epigenetics are at play in how altruistic we choose to be at any given point. Not to mention our views of the person we choose to help (or not to help).

The difference? We can't tell whether someone is "worth helping" off of their appearance. But people do use social behaviour as an indicator. So whilst we don't have green beards, each individual is to some degree a coward, to some degree a sucker, to some degree an altruist and to some degree an impostor. It's the underlying social interactions between you and others that defines which both you and they are in a given interaction. Friends can become enemies, enemies can become friends. Some people fool others to reap the benefits. We might disappoint our family, or help a stranger.

This is (unfortunately still) too complex to model in these kinds of simulations. The "hidden" advantage to altruism is the good will you build up with others. That people remember who helped them. And of course, in the real world, not every act of altruism comes with the risk of death or even detriment (other than time and energy spent). It is why the value of a group of people can be more than the sum of its parts. It's the beauty of co-operation, the basis for which is "trancending" the natural selfishness inherent to all life. I think genetically, we're all capable of altruism, but epigenetical factors dictate how willing we are to be altruistic.

You actually found the answer for proving altruism in your video but missed it.

When you ran many green beard cases where they only saved eachother, a few times they ended up going extinct even though they had a mathematically competitive advantage against cowards.

The important realization is that altruism is a competitive trait for communities not for individuals.

Here is a simulation concept that would show altruisms competitiveness:

1. Overtime predators will eventually kill off a cowardly community

2. Compete many communities against eachother (not just 30) and see which ones end up not going extinct.

Same as the green beards in your example that went extinct due to variance, eventually an altruistic community will survive contrary to probability. Then in the absence of cowards it will thrive.

No green beards are even necessary, it could simply be a lottery, the truth is that an altruistic community is more competitive and enough competitions will cause only the communities that got lucky by eliminating the cowards to not go extinct.

Depending on how much you want to push your simulation, play with the numbers to punish altruism or make it only moderately harmful. The less mathematically competitive you make altruism the more simulations you have to run before you see it work (limit at infinity).

Each of your models followed the same simple principles of mathematical competitiveness. The final case where you introduced imposters simply recreated the original condition of cowards and altruism which we already saw would fail so it obviously never stood a chance.

This is an almost comical bad simulation of biology, as an example if you are altruistic other blobs will help you therefore to keep the population stable it is in the best blobs interest to do so as well as other variables which just aren't accounted for. It's not just basic it's also not a good representation for the basic scenario.

I imagine part of the problem is that this doesn't actually account for the survival of the species as a whole, this species can't go extinct and the "predators" never adapt. But the thing is in the real world who encounters and who gets killed by predators or other dangers isn't random and it's clear that working together, and therefor altruism increases the odds of survival for the entire group. Since predators have better chances when working together it's also clear that prey have better chances at fending off said predators if they work together. A single teenage elephant doesn't really stand a chance against a pack of lions but have a few matriarchs and suddenly the lions are hopelessly outmatched. Furthermore, more complex social interactions give greater benefits to altruism, if you have a large tribe of say a few hundred having one person heroically sacrifice themselves to keep the rest of the tribe alive provides a much bigger benefit than having that same person sacrifice themselves to just save one other person. IRL Genes aren't just passed on by a single person splitting into 2 or 3 like a cell it requires mating so that means that at the very least to have a chance to pass on your genes you also need to attract a mate, that means you inherently need a group to pass on your genes, furthermore with large and long lived animals like humans or elephants it takes a long time to grow up and pregnancy is long and energy consuming process so for that whole time you probably need a group to help both you and the kids. That means that inherently species like humans or other large animals need a group just to reproduce so that means that evolutionary pressures force us to work well with groups and that means being altruistic. Fundamentally we could say that all social cooperation is built on an altruistic assumption since it is impossible to actually know if someone will return the favor, however because this cooperation is so important to us we have evolved to see it as a given that people will return favors as we expect them to (ie. if you pay someone to clean your house you take it as a given that they will do it) and it's also because we see it as a given that we've shaped our society around this cooperation.

Predicting the outcome in the first scenario (no beard) is pretty easy, since there is NO personal benefit to warning the others, only downsides, so there's no trade-off to take into account or anything. In the second scenario you take a risk by issue a warning, but also get the benefit of being warned, so now there's a trade-off, so the outcome is more a matter of the comparing the size of the upside and downside.

I think there is a conceptual error here. With this sort of simulation (same as the one you've done in the past on this topic) who survives is a direct consequence of traits conferring fitness to individuals.
We already know from the start that altruism does not grant fitness to an individual, so the result is a given.
What altruism DOES do, is increasing group fitness. The time you attempted to factor this in with the beard, it was successful in every possible configuration.
The way to not make it so oversimplified and direct, however is not to decouple the traits, but to couple things to something preexisting: genetic distance recognition.
This trait is useful on its own to avoid mutations by mating with an individual with too many similar genes, so it can survive independently.
If you add to this that you are more likely to save your own kid from a burning building than an uncle, and more likely to save an uncle than a random neighbor, and more likely to save a random neighbor than a random useful mammal(pet), and more likely to save a pet than an insect, and more likely to save an insect than some alien abomination..... you get the distinct impression that genetic proximity correlates with altruism.

So instead of recognizing green beards and helping if yes, the blobs should recognize their genetic proximity and be more likely to help the closer the other blob is.
This way no secondary trait is required, and it relies on something that is usually innately known in most living beings.

Furthermore to counteract the initial immediate extinction with low altruist population numbers, some generations of the trait could be silent carriers, by having the trait be recessive for example.

This avoids the appearance of impostors (amogus huhuhuh), unless through very complex methods, and it results in simulating the group fitness increase from altruistic behavior that we have in vivo.

My theory on altruism is that in the real world we all live in a in group and an out group. The equivalent situation in this simulation would be if the alturist would only risk their life if it's another alrurist life on the line while the cowardly out group would be left to die.

Similar thing happened in our world. Those people unable to cooperate and coexist with others would be left to fend for themselves so those traits where selected out. While those that was willing to help was selected in.

Now the real world rarely follows theorycrafting. In our world there are edge cases of antisocial, sociopaths, etc, and pure alturists are also uncommon. Our society has found an equilibrium of sorts.

In humans, we don’t see who a “green beard” is at a glance. Many people will only act with self-destructive altruism toward someone who is known and trusted, often needing to build that trust up for years. Additionally, that trust can typically only be earned through helping one another, even if that help is given with selfish intentions. Very rarely will a person fully fit the “imposter” role in which they only receive help but never return any at all, as people around them will figure out that “the beard is fake”

So blobs judge each other on their reputation. Then you can try different means of making reputation. If the reputation is ideal, it will reflect how many good deeds the blob has done and how many bad deeds.

For example, a good, but not ideal, reputation would be if you had the green beard blobs randomly decide do spend time spying on other blobs, to see if a green beard is a coward (they will see this if the blob cowards out instead of helping a fellow green beard).

Then they must have some sort of system for these spies to share their results with the population. Initially you can have the inspectors be pure and the population trust them. then you can start adding impostor inspectors too, and somehow figure out how the population trusts which inspectors..

I feel like it should be obvious that a perfect imposter is always a strictly dominant economic strategy to being a true beard, since you get the same protection at reduced cost. What the model needs is a way for true beards to adaptively (or at least, frequent) change their signals so that imposters start getting caught out. In the real world, life is so complex that being an imposter all your life is pretty tricky, and we can shame or punish people for not doing the morally right thing when called upon. Likewise, truely good people tend to have opinions and behavioural patterns that signal themselves to others, something that an pretend-good person could imitate but only to high cost, or only when under social observation. For example, if we accidentally find that someone has been doing a kind thing or donating money all their life without making a show and dance about it, so they weren't expecting a social reward, then we have very very strong evidence that they are a true beard. Conversely, people that only give to charity under social duress are likely to be imposters. This gives true beards a means to partially, albeit imperfectly, detect imposters.

Three suggestions, two stolen from other people (and one modified for visual clarity) because I really just wanted to have a compilation of other suggestions in a comment:

-Paired Alleles: there may be a link between having the Altruistic gene and having the Green Beard gene. This could be simulated through either sexual reproduction (though I know you're sticking with asexual for a while now) or through a simple change in the starting demographics. A standard game of Among Us has 1 Impostor for every 4 Crewmates, so (despite the game having literally nothing to do with the sim other than a shared nomenclature) having 20% each of Impostor & Sucker and 30% each of True Beard & Coward would probably lead to a different result than the 25% each explored, and would open up the option of modifying the starting values for those four variations in general, starting values not withstanding.

-Social Reputation: Blobs are clearly capable of communicating with each other - it's how they warn each other of danger! What if blobs could award each other honorary "Blue Beards" or dishonorable "Red Beards" depending on how Suckers and Impostors treat other Blobs. This system could naturally be abused, with Impostors trying to give a True Beard a Red Beard or a Coward a Blue Beard, but the system generally should help benefit both Suckers and True Beards by weeding out (voting off?) Impostors, depending on how much the system is abused.

-Predator Ecosystem: Predators have to survive too! Eating Blobs is a source of nutrition and per generation, successful or unsuccessful Predators have a change of reproducing or dying, leading to a change in the predator dynamic and thus a change in the Blob dynamic. Being Noticed is obviously a bad thing for Predators, so having a separate gene that affects the change of the Predator being Noticed would be a nice (albeit unnecessary since the predator dynamics aren't what we're looking at here) touch. This would also naturally lead to a chance of the Predators going extinct - something that can be used to lead into the Half Wing Problem: a Blob Historian of the Future could ponder what use the Altruism and Green Beard genes had if there was no record of the Predators making them necessary in the first place.

There is another way altruism can be sexually selected for.  Individuals may chose to reproduce with other individuals who have been observed performing altruism.  Interestingly, humans seem to look for mates who are altruistic, but then after having children, altruism for anyone outside the family often receives the negative reward of scolding, presumably because any risk of sacrificing oneself for a non-family member reduces the chances of the family's survival.  The 2nd half of this is just kin selection.  But the sexual selection in favor of altruism is a topic I think has not been adequately explored.

This can only be discouraging against altruism if people really believe behavior is entirely explained by genetics, which in my personal and philosophical experience, it isn't true. Human behavior is complex and determined by the social existence of humans. For instance, in countries that experienced a social collapse in its economic system, or mainly cases of parental negligence, cases of feral children were reported. That is, children raised by other animals. They noticed those children adopted the behavior of the animals that raised them. There were cases of children raised by wolves in Europe, and raised by sheep in Peru.

The genetic explanation of behavior seems to be lacking in explaining these cases. Did these children have genes that adopted a sheep or wolf behavior happening merely by mutation? Seems highly unlikely, don't you think? Altruism, at least in humans, cannot be described in the terms of genetics alone. In my opinion, the best explanation of behavior in humans and some animals is radical behaviorism proposed by Skinner, as it scientifically accurate and based on observations. Lev Vygotsky also has some interesting insights related to human development.

If you're interested in learning more about this, you can read "Psychology and Human Nature", by Peter Ashworth, where in the same book he highlights the features of evolutionary psychology, which seems to be the main premise of this video. He also highlights its profound defects in explaining human behavior.

You are seeing it through the eyes of the prey-only equation.....comparing altruism within a culture that can't affect the surrounding risk factor itself will always fail.

Altruism, in itself, is the sacrifice of self in order for the species to thrive. Saving someone else at the expense of yourself is a zero-sum system....even at 10%, 5%, whatever, doesn't matter, the equation is always net negative acceleration to 0 outcome for the species. The "saving" part needs to be fixed.

Basically....you need to give the ability of the blobs to affect change on the predators, somehow. For example, an altruistic blob would sacrifice themselves to kill (or damage) one of those plant creatures in order to save not only their green-bearded friend, but possibly other blobs in the future. You need a net positive affect of sacrifice in order to see altruism win in any scenario on its own, that's just math.

A few settings that can be tweaked:

plant creatures might need more than 1 attack to die
blobs might survive attacks
plant creatures that feed X times, multiply


Now that is strictly on the DNA aspect....but this is more of a behavioral problem, so environmental learning plays a much bigger role than the genetic factor. This means blob children would follow in tow to their parents for a number of cycles and "learn" how they handle situations. Being a coward while holding children, slows you down and ends up having all of you die....letting your children fend for themselves while you run loses your children so they learn nothing....while altruism sees the parent defend the children, killing the monster at the sacrifice of themselves, but the children survive and learn that. That bond carries further and outwardly, to friendships, relationships, etc. This is how altruism helps the species.
I suspect asexual reproduction is weakening the accuracy of this model somewhat.

As much as I love biology and believe that genetics plays a HUGE role in the functioning of even very complex animal and human behaviours I do wonder sometimes if we have taken the reductionist idea too far. I think altruism in humans, and perhaps animals, often doesn’t affect our survival per say. There are times when it does of course, sharing your scarce food so your neighbour doesn’t starve to death. But a lot of the time it can just be a kind act performed because we are creatures imbued with a rich and complex emotional inner world. Consciousness and empathy allows us to place ourselves in the shoes of another and feel what it feels like for them to suffer, for we have suffered as well. These are powerful drives, ones that can even override our innate self survival instincts. Though I think this is rare except in cases of close family in which case I don’t believe it falls into the category of altruism. So long as it doesn’t harm the survival of the species as a whole I see no reason why it can’t be a trait that survives simply because it doesn’t have a net negative effect.

I feel as though a society composed of nothing but true greenbeards would trend naturally toward further evolving into a superorganism, like a bee hive or an ant colony. Once you have a large collection of creatures fully willing to sacrifice themselves to ensure the survival of the others, it only makes biological sense to concentrate the production of offspring into one defensible portion (even individual) of that collection, and to further specialize roles of the fully eusocial non-reproductive members to better benefit the whole.

In fact, I feel you can relate greenbeard dynamics more broadly to eusocial insect species. Some butterfly larvae – such as Phengaris rebeli – imitate ant offspring to receive food, and then leave the colony after pupating, which is comparable to imposters receiving the benefits of greenbeardism without actually contributing to the wellbeing of other greenbeards. (One major difference there, I suppose, is that P. rebeli is fully reliant on the actual ant colonies for nourishment, and so "outcompeting" its hosts would also result in its own extinction.)

Some proposals for complicating the rules:

1. Start by having a flat percentage chance for whether or not the blobs will reproduce. For every green beard altruist who is SEEN committing an altruistic act, increase the chance that they will successfully reproduce (this could be a floating point percentage based on how close to the center the act was committed). A False Green Beard who eats at a tree where nobody else is eaten has an equal boost to their chances (i.e. A lie that they protected the other blob, even though they'd have run if there was real danger). This is to simulate celebrity.

2. For every Sucker that commits an act of altruism, but does not receive a similar warning, have a chance that they will turn into either a Coward or a Green Beard (provided that they survive). This is to simulate the "Environmental impacts" you mentioned. People can change when they go through a trauma.

3. For every False Green Beard who is SEEN failing to give a warning, have a chance that they will lose the protection of their green beard and become just another Coward. After all, people love gossip.

4. Create a new class of blobs that get to reproduce without needing to go to a tree for food. Instead, they eat a random blob who survived the day. None of the other blobs ever question this or do anything to stop it. This is to simulate the independently wealthy, who operate under different rules, only see each other as 'actual blobs', and are privileged by birth to not have to deal with the consequences of their actions.

There's a few things I can think of that could explain altruism in humans that these models don't cover.
1. Being an imposter isn't strictly limited to inheritance, because every new offspring in nature spawns with a random mutation added onto the combination of its parent genes. You could try coding in imposters (non-altruists, ie. narcissists) with a 0% starting population, where non-imposters have a 10% chance of giving birth to an imposter and imposters have a 50% chance of giving birth to one. Although ultimately even the resilience towards giving birth to certain mutations is in itself controlled by a gene, which it too can be mutated. Unfortunately this level of realism can quickly become too complex for a simulation to really give any further insight.
2. The greatest threat to a species (before the species becomes as dominant as humans today) is not competition within the species (which in this simulation is the limited number of fruit available) but rather the threat of other species, and just the general harsh conditions of nature (which are counteracted by things like making a fire, and it's less wasteful if everyone gathers around the same fire). This is certainly the biggest contributing factor to why humans are altruistic that I know of. I don't know how best to simulate it, but one thing you could try is adding in a predator species (let's call them wolves, and the predators shown in this video snakes) which, in the simulation scenario shown in this video, behaves like blobs except they eat one blob each if the wolves outnumber the blobs at any one tree, and if there are only wolves at a tree, they eat the fruit (one way then to control their population without adding in rabbits, is if a wolf eats fruit they have only a 50% chance of survival - or make them get eaten by the snakes). If the wolves are outnumbered, they run away hungry (unless maybe if they carry a risk-taking gene, where they attack the blobs anyway, with a 50% chance of successfully eating a blob and a 50% chance of being killed, or the rate depending on the ratio). You should then also code in a follower gene that's separate from altruism, which gives a blob a 50% chance of instead of making its own choice, to go to the same tree as a random other blob (and an equivalent gene for the wolves). The altruism gene that you used in this video could then behave similarly for the wolves as it does for the snakes – if the wolves outnumber the blobs, the altruists will try to catch their attention so the wolves only manage to eat half a blob each, while the remaining blobs get a chance to escape.

I think in humans altruism is prevalent only in situations when individuals are not endangering themselves. If there's scarcity of food humans are not really likely to share what they have, but if they have abundance of food they are likely to share it to those that don't. This is where altruism becomes evolutionistically advantageous, because while you are indiscriminately helping both other altruists and selfish individuals, it still increases the numbers of individuals that might be altruist toward you in the future. This is also why while altruist exist, selfish people also do. Both selfish and altruist people benefit from altruists, but if the species had no altruist individuals at all, it would be more likely to go extinct. At the same time altruist individuals can't be altruist to the point where they endanger themselves for others, or they will inevitably decline and vanish. The only exception is when individuals endanger themselves to save their offspring, because that actually increases the probability of their genes to survive.

Extinction is inevitable, because altruism at it's core is counter-productive to survival. Not just in this simulation, but in general. In the most basic of systems, it would involve sharing food that you don't eat yourself. The net benefit is negative. The thing about warning only other blobs with beards is pretty much just a 'cheating' solution really. None of the 'real world' examples are legit. Even species that depend heavily on their hosts surviving, do an insanely careful balancing act in terms of shared resources. They profit within very strict margin and generally there has to be some kind of indirect benefit to the host or other species, or it simply won't work. It's probably best to look into the six types of symbiotic relationships that species can have. You'll see there's really just no such thing as true altruism possible.

Is there a punishment for being a coward?  It seemed like running away would result in a guaranteed survival, where warning resulted in a possible death.  Although they were called "cowards", it is a strategy that leads to the least loss of life.  What if there was some probability of a blob not noticing a predator and they could get eaten before having a chance to either run away or warn?  Running away can lead to the survival of one, but warning can lead to the survival of both.  With the current experiment, there appears to be a risk to warning but not much of a reward for doing so.

This video makes an excellent visualization of some rather simple math intuitions, I would say. We can model this by some simple probability equations. Let P be the starting proportion of altruistic blobs, and 1-P be the starting proportion of Coward blobs, and S be the probability of survival after giving out a warning, and let's assume the chance of either blob detecting the predator is 0.5.

So for each iteration, assuming the population is large, each Altruistic blob has a probability of P of meeting another Altruistic blob, so its chance of survival is 0.5*S+0.5*P, or the chance of it detecting the predator and survive after warning, or the chance of the other blob being Altruistic and detecting the predator, so its chance of survival is 0.5 * (S+P);

For the Coward blob, its chance of survival is 0.5+0.5*P, or the chance of it detecting the predator or the other blob is altruistic, so 0.5*(1+P). With some intuitions, we can see that the blob with greater chance of survival will dominate the population in the end, and the chance of survival for the Coward blob is always greater than that of the Altruistic blob since S<=1.

The same logic can be applied to the more complex simulation, and we can let C be the starting proportion of Coward, I for Imposters, S for Suckers, and G for Greenbeards, and P for surviving after the warning. Their corresponding probability of surviving is:
P(C)=0.5, since it only survives if it detects the predator, and since it doesn't have beard the other side wouldn't warn
P(I)=0.5+0.5*(S+G)=0.5*(1+S+G), since it survives if either it sees the predator or the other blob sees it and is S or G
P(S)=0.5*(S+C)+0.5*P*(G+I)=0.5*(S+C+PG+PI), since it survives if it sees the predator and the other side doesn't have beard, or if it sees the predator and the other side has beard and he survives after giving out the warning.

P(G)=0.5*(S+C)+0.5*P(G+I)+0.5*(G+S)= 0.5*(S+C+PG+PI+G+S), since it survives if it sees the predator and the other side doesn't have beard, or it sees the predator and the other side has beard and it survives, or it doesn't see the predator and other side sees it and will warn him.

We can't determine the exact chance of survival, but we can compare the relative chance of survival. P(C)<=P(I) since S+G>=0; P(S)<=P(G) since G+S>=0; So Coward will go extinct before Impostors, and Suckers will go extinct before Greenbeards. I won't get into rate of change since that will involve calculus and be too much for me, but one thing we can see is if the good guys, green beard, begin to dominate the population, as G->1, P(Impostor) approaches 0.5(1+G) -> 1, while P(G) approaches 0.5(PG+G) and PG <=1, so the bad guys will always win in the end :(.

A quick suggestion from someone with little biology background, maybe try including an influence parameter that if an altruistic blob saves someone, the blob being saved (or blobs in its proximity) has some chance of turning altruistic if it is not already (so we take into account education or societal stimulation/pressure). Maybe that way we can achieve what we are looking for.

Just so people are aware, this isn't exactly a definition of racism, but tribalism, which historically is far far more prevalent, and unlike racism, does have benefits. Basically, you trust your own people more than the other. That is a tribal statement and still exists today. It includes racism, but also covers more personal issues such as family, friends, identity, economics, politics, employment, etc.

Pointing at racism is just what happens when people are made hyper-aware of racism and don't understand the deeper psychology. Racism is pretty much acknowledged as bad, tribalism less so. It's a complicated topic.

Just tossing some ideas: What if a blob that was helped and survived gets some chance of becoming altruistic? After all, as social animals, we aren't just a product of our genes, but of our experiences as well, and we want to keep feats that make us accepted in a group. I believe that even starting with a few "true altruists" in the end we would have a bunch of cases of acquired altruism. Moreover, altruists wouldn't want to stay around the "cowards" who wouldn't want to help them, and the altruists would get fruits only accompanied with other altruists for safety. Also, as altruists would want to stay around other altruists more often, I'd expect them to mate more often with each other, thus spreading the altruistic allele to the next generation.

I'm not exactly satisfied with the final conclusion. The impostors only win out because the altruistic blobs have no way of knowing whether a bearded blob is an impostor or a true beard. A simulation involving "reputation", where the past actions of another blob would affect an altruist's chances of distracting the predator, would probably be better for representing a social species. In the final example, the blobs assume that green beards have to do with altruism when they don't, which probably wouldn't happen for long in the real world. They would find some other strategy to figure out if the other blob is altruistic.

Anyway, nice video. An interesting take on an interesting topic.

I think altruism only makes sense when you compare large social structures. For example:
Take tribe A, which is genetically homogenous, and practices altruism, and tribe B, different and also homogeneous, but not altruistic. Then tribe A will be more successful than tribe B, even though a coward in tribe A would be more succesful than any other member. Eventually, altruistic genes will come to dominate, assuming no mutations.

So the prerequisite for green beard's success is that they can outcast imposters.

The only problem I have with all this is that while you are seeing things what I would consider great representations of natural selection (how many animals have you seen not run when threatened?) - when it comes to social animals there is an important aspect to consider, which is the exchange(trade/barter - whatever you want to call it) that can heavily define the interaction between them. I would say you could have a scenario (and I do think you have touched on this a little bit in the past) where you can test the trading habits between different groups on top of this model and you might have very interesting results. I think this would be more important to understanding altruism in humans as one of our core principles as a species is or economic interactions at pretty much any point of our existence. Now there is also the concept of "language" that can make the system super complex as well (our ability to exchange information), but one step at a time - even bonobos, crows, and racoons understand the concept of trade.

Perhaps in this model you could explore perhaps a "gene" that competes a green-beard/trade variant vs. its opposing set (staying in the 4 category system, if possible). What would they trade? I don't know - but it might be a little prostitution-y, lol.

You would have the tree/predator complex you have here, but add that to a second stage in where if a moog goes to a tree with no other moogs they get two fruits, one of which they can trade. If one moog dies to a predator, the other moog can take both if they were alturistic; if one moog dies and they don't have that relationship, the other will take the chance to at least get one fruit to survive before going home. Moogs that went home with no fruits can take a chance at going and "trading" for a chance of survival. Altruistic Moogs w/no trading will give an extra fruit to anyone who asks, allowing that one to survive. Regular moogs with trading would "trade" a fruit for a 50/50 chance to spawn an extra generation of themselves with a starving moog. Non-trading moogs will simply keep their fruits for survival if they are unable to get food the next round, or they simply get an extra generation each time they do. Altruistic Moogs w/ trading are the interesting ones, as I am not 100% sure how to build it - perhaps they only give fruits to other greenbeards when asked, but trade with any others.

With this, you got the true coward who will run if threatened and will never trade or share; the greenbeard "hippy" that will always give help if they can, but not trade; the "exploiter" who is willing to trade if they have extra for a chance for another exploiter to be born; and the "community" greenbeard who will always freely help other greenbeards, but trade with anyone who isn't to try and increase the "community" population.
Greenbeards who are both at a predator and one dies the other will get both fruits, a greenbeard and a coward at a predator will result in the coward at least getting one if the greenbeard dies (sacrificial), both get none if the greenbeard survives.

I could probably go into more depth and be a bit less rambly, but I do think there is an interesting dynamic here. Not a scientist here, though - just a philosopher.

In the initial example of Altruism vs Cowardice, the Altruistic gene actively hampered survival rates since it reduces genetic fitness. If you got matched up with a Coward, you had a chance to die and evolution doesn't like that. When we switched to green beard Altruism, it combined the guaranteed survival of the Coward and boosted the Survival rates of 2 altruistic beards together, since both of them trigger the escape chance and have a chance of either a net neutral or both escape scenario.

An alternate way to boost survival rates for the Altruistic Gene alone would be that if a coward blob were saved by an Altruistic player, they had some chance to change themselves to altruistic themselves and pass it on (being grateful and changing your habits). This way, being altruistic would increase the population since saving someone adds to the population itself. Definitely an interesting scenario to simulate. Love your content!

I already see a problem as to WHY Altruism failed so much in these runs... And that is because there isn't any real Punishment for Cowardice.

In a realistic setting, Cowardice would result in said coward being treated with Scorn, as they ran off to save their own hides rather than distract the Predator at risk of their own lives, which means they'll do it again and cannot be trusted, thus, making it difficult for the Cowards to acquire a Mate, making the "Cowardice Gene" suffer.

In Primer's setting, the Cowards can Run all the way home and reproduce asexually without the need of a Partner, thus being Rewarded more for running away to save their own hides, and leaving their fellows to die rather than distracting the predator, meaning that the Altruistic ones will die out, leaving the Cowards to "Win" the Experiment.

Much of Primer's simulations have that minor flaw, missing the rather important detail of how Cowardice would actually be treated upon being noticed by their fellows, causing the Brave to die out, and the Cowards to 'Win'.

"if evolution is all about the survival and reproduction of the fittest individuals then why are creatures sometimes nice to each other"
because as organism get smarter, at some point they realise that 2 medium fit individuals are stronger that 1 very fit individual, so cooperation becomes advantageous. The cooperating organism still compete against each other, but the domain of competition has switched towards a set of rules in which other genes are more advantageous.

Also, evolution is not about the survival of individuals, but about the survival of the genetic code. We often value human lifes more than lets say insect lifes, because humans share more genetic code with ourselves. You can actually see that, in that we care more about species that are closer to us genetically, like mammals, than for species that are genetically further away from us, like insects.

Not having watched the full video, I believe that the seemingly inevitable extinction of the altruists can be connected to the fact that the cowards don't bring any risk to themselves by running away, and so are guaranteed to preserve their own life, even if it means the death of another creature. Altruists on the other hand have an inherent risk of getting killed by warning the other creature, who may be a coward and run anyway. There's always a risk of being killed for the altruists, and while it may be a small one, it means that if the altruists cannot reproduce fast enough to balance out that risk, they will inevitably go extinct.
